1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. The fact that we cannot predict what biobanks will be used for in the future bothers me.
2. The biobank owner should be able to sell any information they have about my genes, if they want to.
3. Profits from biobanking should be shared in some way with the community who provided the samples.
4. I don't mind if my samples are connected to my medical records without my prior permission, so long as researchers don't get access to any data that identifies me.
5. It is acceptable for samples and information that doesn't identify me to be sent to researchers overseas.
6. It's OK if data that identifies me is stored in a separate database and replaced in the biobank by a unique non-identifying code.
7. I should be asked for my permission every time researchers want to use my samples for research
8. We should all provide samples to biobanks because it will benefit everyone.
9. People should be paid for providing their samples to a biobank.
10. My sample should never be permanently anonymized since I should be contacted about important research results
11. Religious groups need to be asked for their views about biobanks and genetic research.
12. Commercial companies should keep all the profits they make from biobanking because they take the financial risks and put up the money to develop new drugs and treatments.
13. Information about people's genes and the traits they inherit from their parents is more private than their medical records.
14. Genetic studies of race on ethnic or cultural groups will lead to the discrimination of those groups.
15. Genetic research will improve our lives.
16. I do not mind if researchers have access to my samples, when there is no way I can be identified.
17. High-priced genetic research is diverting funds that could be used to promote public health in other ways.
18. It is always acceptable to do research on samples that identify me, without my prior permission.
19. Biobanks need to be monitored and reviewed by external, independent people to prevent the misuse of data and samples.
20. People who provide samples for research should get special access to the treatments that result from this research.
21. Biobanks will only lead to high profits and expensive treatments that most people can't afford.
22. Permission from the indigenous community must be sought if samples are collected from indigenous peoples.
23. There is no risk to the people who provide samples and information to biobanks.
24. Collecting samples from people in an ethnic or cultural group is acceptable only if the whole group has agreed to participate.
25. Improved health is more likely to come from educating people about their diet and lifestyle than from biobanks.
26. There must be special consideration of the views of Aboriginal people towards healthcare and genetic research.
27. Researchers and institutions (e.g. hospitals and universities) should be allowed to use samples for research but they should not own them.
28. People should always be able to withdraw their sample from research at any time.
29. Biobanks are valuable even if they only advance science (e.g. provide new information about diseases) and do not lead to treatments or cures.
30. There is no point asking the public for their views on the ethical issues in science and technology.
31. The public will be more protected if biobanks are government-funded not privately funded.
32. Deciding how to regulate biobanks should be left to the government.
33. Commercial companies should get access to biobanks, otherwise new drugs and treatments will not be developed.
34. I trust researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
35. I do not mind if my sample is connected to my name and medical information.
36. Biobanks are valuable because they promise huge benefits for our economy.
37. Policy makers need to consider whether WA should not have biobanks.
38. I trust independent research ethics committees, which are not connected to the biobank in anyway, to decide whether research is ethical and approve who gets access to my samples.
39. People should be told if commercial companies could get access to their samples and information.
40. People who provide samples should be active in the set up and ongoing management of biobanks.
41. The priorities for health should be to reduce inequalities and the burden of disease.
42. The confidentiality of personal medical information is critical in any circumstance where research is being conducted.
43. I trust biobanks with managers who are independent of researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
44. The community that provides samples for research should receive improved medical services in return.
45. Race is a useful topic for genetic studies
46. I should have property rights to my tissues before and after they leave my body
47. People with a [chronic disease or] genetic condition in their family have a responsibility to be involved in genetic research.
48. Public funds should pay for biobanks, instead of private companies.
49. Genetic studies will lead to the discrimination of people living with genetic conditions or disabilities.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Minimal Government Input: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Fairly relaxed oversight of use of biobanks and  privacy provisions (low level of regulation).
2. Publicly Funded with minimal regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
3. Cautious Implementation: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Very strict oversight of use of biobanks and strong privacy provisions.
4. Privately Funded with strong regulation: A BB system where funding is provided mostly by private companies, withstrong government oversight and privacy provisions.
5. Publicly Funded with strong regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
6. High Privacy: Implementation of a (publicy or privately owned) biobanking system where privacy of individuals is paramount. Stored data and biological samples for research requires the authorization of individual donors.
7. Privately Funded with minimal regulation: Minimal regulation of privately run biobanking system with maximum participation of the public. Low privacy provisions.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritized strong regulation and public funding for biobanking to ensure privacy and public benefit.

5. Everyone in Queensland is better off for having a road like the Bloomfield Track.

15. I'm concerned that I will be made worse off by any decision about the Bloomfield Track.
16. The fate of the Bloomfield Track is of no concern to me.
17. The Bloomfield Track may not have been the best idea, but I guess there is probably little point in closing it now that it has been built.
18. I don't know how, but I think that there must be some way in which everybody benefits from protecting the rainforest near the Bloomfield Track.
19. Conservation in the Daintree area is worthwhile at whatever cost.

21. I'm not sure if the future of the Bloomfield Track should be determined by locals, outsiders or both.
22. When it comes to the Bloomfield Track, it's not important to worry about what the future will hold
23. Using cars on the Bloomfield Track is bad for the rainforest.
24. I don't know what the people of Bloomfield think about the Bloomfield Track.
25. I don't really know who benefits most from the protection of Rainforest in the Daintree.
26. The coral reefs along the foreshore below the Bloomfield Track are not badly affected by the road.
27. The protection of plants and animals in the Daintree is OK so long as it doesn't affect me.
28. A long term perspective on the Bloomfield Track is essential.
29. The Bloomfield Track issue is important for Queensland.
30. Whilst impacts on locals in the Bloomfield area are a concern, it is the broader community that should carry more weight when deciding what to do with the Bloomfield Track.
31. I don't like how development is creeping further and further North into the Daintree and beyond because of its effect on the environment.
32. Any decision about the Bloomfield Track will greatly affect people like me.
33. Native animals in the Daintree need protection because they have a right to life which cannot be traded against economic considerations.
34. Laying bitumen on the Bloomfield Track would be beneficial for the environment
35. The Bloomfield Track is important because it allows quick access to remote areas of the North.
36. I have no idea what the people in the Bloomfield area think about the Bloomfield Track.
37. Erosion from the Bloomfield Track is permanently damaging the coral reefs that fringe the beaches below
38. The future of the Bloomfield Track should be determined by everyone and not just by those who live in the Bloomfield area.
39. If we don't take steps to protect the Daintree Rainforest future generations will miss out on the opportunity to experience the area as we do now.
40. There is no reason to believe that the Daintree Rainforest is under threat.
41. If the Bloomfield Track is sealed (bitumenized) there will not be a rapid increase in environmentally damaging development in the Daintree area in the future It may even benefit the environment there.

- Rate each of the 42 [Considerations] below from 1 to 12, where 1 is strongly disagree and 12 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 42 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 42 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. I'm concerned that I will be made worse off by any decision about the Bloomfield Track.
2. In deciding on what to do with the Bloomfield Track I don't know whether it's more important to meet the needs of the community or the environment.
3. I think that both short and long term perspectives are needed in deciding what should be done with the Bloomfield Track, but I don't know which one is more important.
4. The fate of the Bloomfield Track is of no concern to me.
5. If the Bloomfield Track is sealed (bitumenized) there will not be a rapid increase in environmentally damaging development in the Daintree area in the future It may even benefit the environment there.
6. Economic development associated with the Bloomfield Track will provide more opportunities for future generations in North Queensland.
7. The Wujal Wujal Community is better off now that the Bloomfield Track has been built.
8. Erosion from the Bloomfield Track is permanently damaging the coral reefs that fringe the beaches below
9. The Bloomfield Track may not have been the best idea, but I guess there is probably little point in closing it now that it has been built.
10. The coral reefs along the foreshore below the Bloomfield Track are not badly affected by the road.
11. Laying bitumen on the Bloomfield Track would be beneficial for the environment
12. No development should be permitted in World Heritage areas such as the Daintree.
13. If we don't take steps to protect the Daintree Rainforest future generations will miss out on the opportunity to experience the area as we do now.
14. The Bloomfield Track issue is important for Queensland.
15. I'm not sure if the future of the Bloomfield Track should be determined by locals, outsiders or both.
16. The more that it is possible for the average North Queensland resident can access the Bloomfield Track the better
17. The future of the Bloomfield Track should be determined by everyone and not just by those who live in the Bloomfield area.
18. The Bloomfield Track is important because it allows quick access to remote areas of the North.
19. The road is just the 'thin edge of the wedge'. This may not happen for a long time, but it will happen.
20. I don't like how development is creeping further and further North into the Daintree and beyond because of its effect on the environment.
21. I don't really know who benefits most from the protection of Rainforest in the Daintree.
22. Native animals in the Daintree need protection because they have a right to life which cannot be traded against economic considerations.
23. I would be worse off if more of the Daintree rainforest is protected.
24. I don't know if improving the Bloomfield Track would lead to a rapid acceleration of development in the area to the detriment of the environment.
25. I don't know what the people of Bloomfield think about the Bloomfield Track.
26. A long term perspective on the Bloomfield Track is essential.
27. Using cars on the Bloomfield Track is bad for the rainforest.
28. Any decision about the Bloomfield Track will greatly affect people like me.
29. When it comes to the Bloomfield track, people living in Cairns are in no position to judge what the interests of the local residents of Bloomfield are.
30. The most important use of the Bloomfield Track is for tourism.
31. There is no reason to believe that the Daintree Rainforest is under threat.
32. Let's fix the problems in the Daintree just for now. The future will take care of itself.
33. I have no idea what the people in the Bloomfield area think about the Bloomfield Track.
34. Conservation in the Daintree area is worthwhile at whatever cost.
35. When it comes to the Bloomfield Track, it's not important to worry about what the future will hold
36. We don't need to worry too much about environmental damage in the Daintree region because future generations will be better able to deal with these problems than we are.
37. If future generations could have their say about the Bloomfield track, they would be less concerned about the environmental impacts than many people make out.
38. Everyone in Queensland is better off for having a road like the Bloomfield Track.
39. Whilst impacts on locals in the Bloomfield area are a concern, it is the broader community that should carry more weight when deciding what to do with the Bloomfield Track.
40. I don't know how, but I think that there must be some way in which everybody benefits from protecting the rainforest near the Bloomfield Track.
41. Erosion from the Bloomfield Track does not cause siltation or damage to the fringing inshore reefs between Cape Tribulation and Cooktown
42. The protection of plants and animals in the Daintree is OK so long as it doesn't affect me.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 5 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 5, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 5 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 5 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 5 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Stabilize specific trouble spots, such as steep slopes, on the road but leave it as a 4WD track.
2. Close the road and rehabilitate it.
3. Maintain the road in its current condition as a 4WD track.
4. Upgrade the track to a bitumen road.
5. Upgrade the road, to a dirt road suitable for conventional vehicles.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritizing environmental protection and minimizing development in the Daintree area.

## [Example output]:

2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. If future generations could have their say about the Bloomfield track, they would be less concerned about the environmental impacts than many people make out.
2. The most important use of the Bloomfield Track is for tourism.
3. I don't know what the people of Bloomfield think about the Bloomfield Track.
4. The coral reefs along the foreshore below the Bloomfield Track are not badly affected by the road.
5. The Bloomfield Track is important because it allows quick access to remote areas of the North.
6. The protection of plants and animals in the Daintree is OK so long as it doesn't affect me.
7. Laying bitumen on the Bloomfield Track would be beneficial for the environment
8. Any decision about the Bloomfield Track will greatly affect people like me.
9. The future of the Bloomfield Track should be determined by everyone and not just by those who live in the Bloomfield area.
10. Everyone in Queensland is better off for having a road like the Bloomfield Track.
11. I would be worse off if more of the Daintree rainforest is protected.
12. Conservation in the Daintree area is worthwhile at whatever cost.
13. Using cars on the Bloomfield Track is bad for the rainforest.
14. I'm concerned that I will be made worse off by any decision about the Bloomfield Track.
15. I don't really know who benefits most from the protection of Rainforest in the Daintree.
16. Erosion from the Bloomfield Track is permanently damaging the coral reefs that fringe the beaches below
17. I have no idea what the people in the Bloomfield area think about the Bloomfield Track.
18. I don't like how development is creeping further and further North into the Daintree and beyond because of its effect on the environment.
19. We don't need to worry too much about environmental damage in the Daintree region because future generations will be better able to deal with these problems than we are.
20. The fate of the Bloomfield Track is of no concern to me.
21. I don't know how, but I think that there must be some way in which everybody benefits from protecting the rainforest near the Bloomfield Track.
22. If the Bloomfield Track is sealed (bitumenized) there will not be a rapid increase in environmentally damaging development in the Daintree area in the future It may even benefit the environment there.
23. No development should be permitted in World Heritage areas such as the Daintree.
24. The Wujal Wujal Community is better off now that the Bloomfield Track has been built.
25. A long term perspective on the Bloomfield Track is essential.
26. There is no reason to believe that the Daintree Rainforest is under threat.
27. In deciding on what to do with the Bloomfield Track I don't know whether it's more important to meet the needs of the community or the environment.
28. Native animals in the Daintree need protection because they have a right to life which cannot be traded against economic considerations.
29. The more that it is possible for the average North Queensland resident can access the Bloomfield Track the better
30. If we don't take steps to protect the Daintree Rainforest future generations will miss out on the opportunity to experience the area as we do now.
31. I don't know if improving the Bloomfield Track would lead to a rapid acceleration of development in the area to the detriment of the environment.
32. I think that both short and long term perspectives are needed in deciding what should be done with the Bloomfield Track, but I don't know which one is more important.
33. When it comes to the Bloomfield Track, it's not important to worry about what the future will hold
34. When it comes to the Bloomfield track, people living in Cairns are in no position to judge what the interests of the local residents of Bloomfield are.
35. The Bloomfield Track issue is important for Queensland.
36. Economic development associated with the Bloomfield Track will provide more opportunities for future generations in North Queensland.
37. I'm not sure if the future of the Bloomfield Track should be determined by locals, outsiders or both.
38. Let's fix the problems in the Daintree just for now. The future will take care of itself.
39. The road is just the 'thin edge of the wedge'. This may not happen for a long time, but it will happen.
40. The Bloomfield Track may not have been the best idea, but I guess there is probably little point in closing it now that it has been built.
41. Whilst impacts on locals in the Bloomfield area are a concern, it is the broader community that should carry more weight when deciding what to do with the Bloomfield Track.
42. Erosion from the Bloomfield Track does not cause siltation or damage to the fringing inshore reefs between Cape Tribulation and Cooktown

2. Any decision about the Bloomfield Track will greatly affect people like me.
3. In deciding on what to do with the Bloomfield Track I don't know whether it's more important to meet the needs of the community or the environment.
4. No development should be permitted in World Heritage areas such as the Daintree.
5. I think that both short and long term perspectives are needed in deciding what should be done with the Bloomfield Track, but I don't know which one is more important.
6. The future of the Bloomfield Track should be determined by everyone and not just by those who live in the Bloomfield area.
7. If future generations could have their say about the Bloomfield track, they would be less concerned about the environmental impacts than many people make out.
8. The more that it is possible for the average North Queensland resident can access the Bloomfield Track the better
9. I don't know if improving the Bloomfield Track would lead to a rapid acceleration of development in the area to the detriment of the environment.
10. The most important use of the Bloomfield Track is for tourism.
11. Laying bitumen on the Bloomfield Track would be beneficial for the environment
12. If we don't take steps to protect the Daintree Rainforest future generations will miss out on the opportunity to experience the area as we do now.
13. Let's fix the problems in the Daintree just for now. The future will take care of itself.
14. I don't really know who benefits most from the protection of Rainforest in the Daintree.
15. I'm concerned that I will be made worse off by any decision about the Bloomfield Track.
16. There is no reason to believe that the Daintree Rainforest is under threat.
17. Economic development associated with the Bloomfield Track will provide more opportunities for future generations in North Queensland.
18. The Wujal Wujal Community is better off now that the Bloomfield Track has been built.
19. Erosion from the Bloomfield Track is permanently damaging the coral reefs that fringe the beaches below
20. Native animals in the Daintree need protection because they have a right to life which cannot be traded against economic considerations.
21. I don't know how, but I think that there must be some way in which everybody benefits from protecting the rainforest near the Bloomfield Track.
22. We don't need to worry too much about environmental damage in the Daintree region because future generations will be better able to deal with these problems than we are.
23. I'm not sure if the future of the Bloomfield Track should be determined by locals, outsiders or both.
24. A long term perspective on the Bloomfield Track is essential.
25. The Bloomfield Track issue is important for Queensland.
26. I don't know what the people of Bloomfield think about the Bloomfield Track.
27. I would be worse off if more of the Daintree rainforest is protected.
28. The road is just the 'thin edge of the wedge'. This may not happen for a long time, but it will happen.
29. I have no idea what the people in the Bloomfield area think about the Bloomfield Track.
30. If the Bloomfield Track is sealed (bitumenized) there will not be a rapid increase in environmentally damaging development in the Daintree area in the future It may even benefit the environment there.
31. Using cars on the Bloomfield Track is bad for the rainforest.
32. Everyone in Queensland is better off for having a road like the Bloomfield Track.
33. The coral reefs along the foreshore below the Bloomfield Track are not badly affected by the road.
34. Erosion from the Bloomfield Track does not cause siltation or damage to the fringing inshore reefs between Cape Tribulation and Cooktown
35. The Bloomfield Track is important because it allows quick access to remote areas of the North.
36. The fate of the Bloomfield Track is of no concern to me.
37. The Bloomfield Track may not have been the best idea, but I guess there is probably little point in closing it now that it has been built.
38. The protection of plants and animals in the Daintree is OK so long as it doesn't affect me.
39. When it comes to the Bloomfield track, people living in Cairns are in no position to judge what the interests of the local residents of Bloomfield are.
40. Whilst impacts on locals in the Bloomfield area are a concern, it is the broader community that should carry more weight when deciding what to do with the Bloomfield Track.
41. Conservation in the Daintree area is worthwhile at whatever cost.
42. When it comes to the Bloomfield Track, it's not important to worry about what the future will hold

## [Considerations]:
1. We are a democratic country.
2. If Australia is to recover from the horrible mess we are in at present, we will need leaders of high principles, who will govern with honesty, justice, and righteousness, fearlessly putting into practice the principles of the Bible.
3. I'm always cynical about government processes.
4. We suffer a Parliamentary Democracy and an archaic and conflict oriented, "two party system" where one of two main parties will manipulate us for the next few years. 
5. We as individuals have a right, that's what democracy means to me
6. There is no real difference in ideological terms between the major parties and preference distributions are problematic.
7. In Australia the rich have virtually unlimited access to the legal system and the capacity to use it to achieve their own ends.
8. Concluding that some races/cultures are better than others must be avoided.
9. I don't know too much about democracy. I feel ridiculous voting.
10. We live in a great democracy.
11. The fundamental dynamic of Australian society is that it is one of evolution, not revolution.
12. A lot of people may be politically ignorant, but they believe what they see and hear on television, and that makes them vote the way they do. They have been brainwashed by the clever advertising people.
13. Democracy means that all policy is exposed to open discussion and debate in a public political space of all citizens before being put to a transparent, accountable vote.
14. The true believers are about decency in life, about a capacity to debate the issues and to receive different views.
15. You don't have to wait three years to say 'I'm not happy with the job you did.' You can apply pressure, and enough people writing to the local member can turn the situation around.
16. Republicanism is a smokescreen for democratic treachery, incompetence and lunacy.
17. Free markets work because individual people, cooperating peacefully and voluntarily through markets, can achieve much that politicians and bureaucrats cannot achieve using compulsion and direction.

2. The last thing we need is a Canberra 'Big Brother' telling us what we should read and hear.

4. The true function of government is to maintain peace and justice. This does not include interfering in private transactions of its electors.
5. Until women are equally represented in Australian parliaments, we will not have a genuine representative democracy.
6. A lot of people may be politically ignorant, but they believe what they see and hear on television, and that makes them vote the way they do. They have been brainwashed by the clever advertising people.
7. Sometimes I get a bit worried that there's a lot of small minority groups that tend to get a lot of the say
8. We should strengthen protections of the free press in order to facilitate a more open and publicly accountable government. 
9. There is a lot of consultation by govt – but who is listening?  And what power do they have to make changes?
10. Democracy is a term which has lost much of its original meaning.
11. We live in a great democracy.
12. People get the government they deserve
13. Democracy means we, the people, are responsible for what government does, or fails to do.
14. We as individuals have a right, that's what democracy means to me

17. I don't want to be in a place where only a minority's viewpoint gets the right to say what's going to happen.
18. I don't know too much about democracy. I feel ridiculous voting.
19. Low female participation rates compound the domination of the public realm by males.
20. I don't think we have a lot of input into legislation and a lot of things that are important.
21. There is no real difference in ideological terms between the major parties and preference distributions are problematic.
22. The only time we are all equal is when we vote in the ballot box.
23. I'm always cynical about government processes.
24. You don't have to wait three years to say 'I'm not happy with the job you did.' You can apply pressure, and enough people writing to the local member can turn the situation around.
25. Democracy means that all policy is exposed to open discussion and debate in a public political space of all citizens before being put to a transparent, accountable vote.
26. People are quite capable of processing and thinking about the vast majority of issues facing our society but as long as we are subjected to 'news lite' the level of political debate will remain facile. 
27. If Australia is to recover from the horrible mess we are in at present, we will need leaders of high principles, who will govern with honesty, justice, and righteousness, fearlessly putting into practice the principles of the Bible.
28. Our community and nation should invoke a spirit that you are important, that you do have a way of influencing things.
29. Our political system's strength is that it can change to meet changing circumstances.
30. Republicanism is a smokescreen for democratic treachery, incompetence and lunacy.
31. In Australia the rich have virtually unlimited access to the legal system and the capacity to use it to achieve their own ends.
32. The fundamental dynamic of Australian society is that it is one of evolution, not revolution.
33. It would be a great thing if voters could vote on specific issues, not only on a whole party program at election time.
34. Proportional Representation also forces parties to coalesce and moderates out the extreme political views. 
35. I don't think there's anything wrong with people voting for their self-interest.
36. We suffer a Parliamentary Democracy and an archaic and conflict oriented, "two party system" where one of two main parties will manipulate us for the next few years. 
37. The true believers are about decency in life, about a capacity to debate the issues and to receive different views.
38. Free markets work because individual people, cooperating peacefully and voluntarily through markets, can achieve much that politicians and bureaucrats cannot achieve using compulsion and direction.
39. Concluding that some races/cultures are better than others must be avoided.
40. Our government is attempting to mould our society to the needs of a profit-oriented market
41. There's a dollar democracy that runs through our supposed democracy.
42. In the Senate there should be elected representatives who are not from the major parties but from smaller interest groups.
43. We should not be afraid of disagreement. Indeed, an important feature of a liberal democracy is respect for conflicting ideas; difference is part of the human condition. 
44. We are a democratic country.
45. The people we elect are loyal not to we dumb bunnies who elected them, but the agenda and dogma of their party. 
46. I suppose we do have an upper class and a lower class.
47. Governments can talk a great game about 'democracy'. They fall down, in practice, because they cannot accept any sharing of the power to influence decisions with those who might have different motives and ideas.
48. The party system is the main obstruction to accountable politics.

13. I don't know too much about democracy. I feel ridiculous voting.

- Rate each of the 48 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 48 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 48 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. If you want your vote to count for anything, then you need to not vote in ignorance, you need to know something about what you're being offered.
2. We as individuals have a right, that's what democracy means to me
3. The people we elect are loyal not to we dumb bunnies who elected them, but the agenda and dogma of their party. 
4. The party system is the main obstruction to accountable politics.
5. The only time we are all equal is when we vote in the ballot box.
6. Democracy means that all policy is exposed to open discussion and debate in a public political space of all citizens before being put to a transparent, accountable vote.
7. In Australia the rich have virtually unlimited access to the legal system and the capacity to use it to achieve their own ends.
8. Our political system's strength is that it can change to meet changing circumstances.
9. There is no real difference in ideological terms between the major parties and preference distributions are problematic.
10. People get the government they deserve
11. Our community and nation should invoke a spirit that you are important, that you do have a way of influencing things.
12. We live in a great democracy.
13. I suppose we do have an upper class and a lower class.
14. I don't think there's anything wrong with people voting for their self-interest.
15. There is a lot of consultation by govt – but who is listening?  And what power do they have to make changes?
16. Our government is attempting to mould our society to the needs of a profit-oriented market
17. Low female participation rates compound the domination of the public realm by males.
18. Governments can talk a great game about 'democracy'. They fall down, in practice, because they cannot accept any sharing of the power to influence decisions with those who might have different motives and ideas.
19. I'm always cynical about government processes.
20. I don't think we have a lot of input into legislation and a lot of things that are important.
21. Too few people have a lot of sway in the system.  Corporate lobbyists, vested interests, pork barrelling and contributions to political parties are all problematic.
22. Democracy is a term which has lost much of its original meaning.
23. The fundamental dynamic of Australian society is that it is one of evolution, not revolution.
24. The last thing we need is a Canberra 'Big Brother' telling us what we should read and hear.
25. Until women are equally represented in Australian parliaments, we will not have a genuine representative democracy.
26. A lot of people may be politically ignorant, but they believe what they see and hear on television, and that makes them vote the way they do. They have been brainwashed by the clever advertising people.
27. Free markets work because individual people, cooperating peacefully and voluntarily through markets, can achieve much that politicians and bureaucrats cannot achieve using compulsion and direction.
28. We suffer a Parliamentary Democracy and an archaic and conflict oriented, "two party system" where one of two main parties will manipulate us for the next few years. 
29. Not voting is a form of expression. It's a way of telling parties that no one is offering policies that appeal to you.
30. I don't want to be in a place where only a minority's viewpoint gets the right to say what's going to happen.
31. We are a democratic country.
32. We should not be afraid of disagreement. Indeed, an important feature of a liberal democracy is respect for conflicting ideas; difference is part of the human condition. 
33. Proportional Representation also forces parties to coalesce and moderates out the extreme political views. 
34. I don't know too much about democracy. I feel ridiculous voting.
35. Sometimes I get a bit worried that there's a lot of small minority groups that tend to get a lot of the say
36. It would be a great thing if voters could vote on specific issues, not only on a whole party program at election time.
37. The true function of government is to maintain peace and justice. This does not include interfering in private transactions of its electors.
38. We should strengthen protections of the free press in order to facilitate a more open and publicly accountable government. 
39. The political system is remote and closed and the connection with elected representatives is difficult, they are often faceless.
40. In the Senate there should be elected representatives who are not from the major parties but from smaller interest groups.
41. Concluding that some races/cultures are better than others must be avoided.
42. Democracy means we, the people, are responsible for what government does, or fails to do.
43. The true believers are about decency in life, about a capacity to debate the issues and to receive different views.
44. There's a dollar democracy that runs through our supposed democracy.
45. You don't have to wait three years to say 'I'm not happy with the job you did.' You can apply pressure, and enough people writing to the local member can turn the situation around.
46. People are quite capable of processing and thinking about the vast majority of issues facing our society but as long as we are subjected to 'news lite' the level of political debate will remain facile. 
47. Republicanism is a smokescreen for democratic treachery, incompetence and lunacy.
48. If Australia is to recover from the horrible mess we are in at present, we will need leaders of high principles, who will govern with honesty, justice, and righteousness, fearlessly putting into practice the principles of the Bible.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 5 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 5, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 5 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 5 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 5 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. The kind of government that we have, with no major changes
2. Government with guaranteed involvement by all social groups, especially those representing disadvantaged minorities, in policy making
3. Government with strong leaders and legislation that ensures that proper moral principles are observed in society.
4. Government that abolishes all policies that give special benefits to minority groups, and instead ensures equal influence for all Australians
5. A government with constitutional rules specifying its main task is to ensure that economic markets work well, and that government intervenes as little in society beyond that

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritized inclusive and representative governance over economic or moral focuses.

6. Policies that involve a dramatic cut back in CO2 emissions (by 50% in the next 10 years).
7. Preparing for climate risk through the development of new approaches and technologies that enhance resilience to the impacts of climate variability or change.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritizing dramatic emissions cuts and adaptation policies to address urgent climate change concerns.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Forests must contribute to the economic stability of forest-dependent communities.  There are many job opportunities and value-added products that come out of the forest such as wood for art, vigas for building homes, wildlife for food, herbs for medicine, and grass for livestock.
2. Science is the most important component informing all management decisions — more so than social, cultural and economic considerations.
3. Traditional, sustainable forestry that benefits local economies and maintains rural livelihoods is much better than large scale corporate forestry.
4. Federal forest management policy should make it easier for loggers to thin out backcountry forests by easing regulatory restrictions and making it harder for interest groups to stop or delay that work.
5. Federal agencies need to restore public trust through transparency in project intent, development and implementation.
6. People should take what is needed from forests, but in a context of stewardship and sustainable use and interaction with nature. 
7. Needless red tape and lawsuits delay effective implementation of forest health projects on public lands.
8. Returning forests to presettlement conditions ignores the need for wildlife that are adapted to current forest conditions by mandating drastic thinning virtually overnight. 
9. The increased density of forests in the West has not damaged ecosystems.
10. Forest restoration projects should be done in all areas of the forest including roadless and wilderness areas.
11. Stakeholders in forest management should work together to define management objectives more by experiments and adaptive management. 
12. We need active forest management on our public lands, through thinning and prescribed burns to reduce the unnatural buildup of fuels.
13. Forest health means jobs.
14. Forest management involves restoring ecosystem function and processes that maintain ecosystems over the long run. 
15. Prescribed burning is needed to restore fire-adapted ecosystems.
16. A diameter cap should be placed on all thinning projects to ensure large trees are not cut.
17. Prescribed burns are a flawed idea, especially when there are other practices available for restoration.
18. Natural resources must be developed for the benefit of the plain American citizen.
19. We should not manipulate nature by restoring forest conditions.
20. Using citizen participation in forest management is very important for basing decisions on different ideas and cultural values along with science. 
21. Fire risk reduction projects should clearly focus on the wildland-urban interface, avoiding treatments in roadless areas.
22. If an action is determined to be necessary to control a wildfire, save lives and/or property, and ensure that fire crews can do their jobs safely and efficiently, then it is appropriate to act even if it results in the take of an endangered species.
23. Humans are a part of the environment. We need to learn how to live sustainably with that environment as much as possible. 
24. We need to be cautious: the solution is there, but we still have a lot to learn. If we just jump in, we're going to make mistakes.
25. The government is advancing timber sales in the name of ecological restoration.
26. All fuels treatment projects on public lands should comply with existing environmental laws even if compliance slows implementation.
27. Land managers should return public forest land to natural conditions and fire cycles that are specific to each forest-type.
28. Environmental organizations have moved the management of our forests to where it is being done by emotion and not by science.
29. Small scale thinning projects should give the communities involved pride in taking part in a sustainable forest management plan, and it also allows the traditional communities to realize a boost to their fragile economies.
30. We have to move forward with large-scale restoration-based fuel reduction and learn as we go.
31. Aggressive fire suppression has caused the majority of the problems regarding  fires. 
32. Forest lands should be brought back to their state before human intervention began.
33. Forest health needs restoring after decades of government mismanagement.
34. Old Growth protection is necessary in order to preserve and protect the viability of species dependent upon Old Growth ecosystems.
35. The main issue in forest management is to protect loss of life and property due to catastrophic wildfire. 
36. To make thinning projects cost effective, private logging companies must be able to log larger trees.
37. Large trees must be removed in order to create openings for wildlife habitat. 
38. Without public participation there will be conflict, whereas participation leads to cooperation.
39. We need to allow forest managers to determine how to improve forest health to minimize fire damage and loss.
40. We need to experiment with a range of treatments that could meet restoration goals. 
41. Thinning efforts should focus entirely on the small trees that make up the vast majority of the fire risk in the forest. 
42. We need to clean up the bureaucratic maze that stops our professional foresters from being able to do the work that they are trained to do.
43. Demonizing fire is a mistake: we must accept risks of fire damage to property and implement controlled burning.
44. Federal land management procedures are so complex that they prevent timely action to address ecological crises on public lands.
45. Fire is a natural and vital component of most western forest ecosystems.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Management that favors aggressive reduction of hazardous fuels
2. Management that favors local-based harvesting for fuel and timber needs.
3. Management that prioritizes the location and level of treatments favoring both ecological and social values (i.e. wildlife, watersheds, community protection, special cultural places).
4. Management that favors the protection of wildlife and wildlife habitat.
5. Management that favors treatments to restore structure, function and composition of the forest to presettlement conditions, and allowing the introduction of fire as a natural disturbance.
6. No fire or fuels management. Leaving the forests as they stand without active management.
7. Management that favors thinning treatments to realize economic gain.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritized balanced management that considers ecological and social values.

6. Forest lands should be brought back to their state before human intervention began.

8. We need to be cautious: the solution is there, but we still have a lot to learn. If we just jump in, we're going to make mistakes.
9. Fire risk reduction projects should clearly focus on the wildland-urban interface, avoiding treatments in roadless areas.

14. Prescribed burns are a flawed idea, especially when there are other practices available for restoration.
15. Forest restoration projects should be done in all areas of the forest including roadless and wilderness areas.
16. Federal land management procedures are so complex that they prevent timely action to address ecological crises on public lands.
17. Forest health needs restoring after decades of government mismanagement.
18. Forest management involves restoring ecosystem function and processes that maintain ecosystems over the long run. 
19. Prescribed burning is needed to restore fire-adapted ecosystems.
20. Natural resources must be developed for the benefit of the plain American citizen.
21. Federal forest management policy should make it easier for loggers to thin out backcountry forests by easing regulatory restrictions and making it harder for interest groups to stop or delay that work.
22. We should not manipulate nature by restoring forest conditions.
23. Old Growth protection is necessary in order to preserve and protect the viability of species dependent upon Old Growth ecosystems.
24. Thinning efforts should focus entirely on the small trees that make up the vast majority of the fire risk in the forest. 
25. Small scale thinning projects should give the communities involved pride in taking part in a sustainable forest management plan, and it also allows the traditional communities to realize a boost to their fragile economies.
26. Environmental organizations have moved the management of our forests to where it is being done by emotion and not by science.
27. Demonizing fire is a mistake: we must accept risks of fire damage to property and implement controlled burning.
28. Large trees must be removed in order to create openings for wildlife habitat. 
29. We need to allow forest managers to determine how to improve forest health to minimize fire damage and loss.
30. Traditional, sustainable forestry that benefits local economies and maintains rural livelihoods is much better than large scale corporate forestry.
31. Needless red tape and lawsuits delay effective implementation of forest health projects on public lands.
32. We need active forest management on our public lands, through thinning and prescribed burns to reduce the unnatural buildup of fuels.
33. All fuels treatment projects on public lands should comply with existing environmental laws even if compliance slows implementation.
34. Forests must contribute to the economic stability of forest-dependent communities.  There are many job opportunities and value-added products that come out of the forest such as wood for art, vigas for building homes, wildlife for food, herbs for medicine, and grass for livestock.
35. Fire is a natural and vital component of most western forest ecosystems.
36. The increased density of forests in the West has not damaged ecosystems.
37. We need to experiment with a range of treatments that could meet restoration goals. 
38. A diameter cap should be placed on all thinning projects to ensure large trees are not cut.
39. Stakeholders in forest management should work together to define management objectives more by experiments and adaptive management. 
40. Land managers should return public forest land to natural conditions and fire cycles that are specific to each forest-type.
41. If an action is determined to be necessary to control a wildfire, save lives and/or property, and ensure that fire crews can do their jobs safely and efficiently, then it is appropriate to act even if it results in the take of an endangered species.
42. Forest health means jobs.
43. Science is the most important component informing all management decisions — more so than social, cultural and economic considerations.
44. Using citizen participation in forest management is very important for basing decisions on different ideas and cultural values along with science. 
45. The main issue in forest management is to protect loss of life and property due to catastrophic wildfire.

6. Large trees must be removed in order to create openings for wildlife habitat. 
7. We need active forest management on our public lands, through thinning and prescribed burns to reduce the unnatural buildup of fuels.
8. If an action is determined to be necessary to control a wildfire, save lives and/or property, and ensure that fire crews can do their jobs safely and efficiently, then it is appropriate to act even if it results in the take of an endangered species.
9. Natural resources must be developed for the benefit of the plain American citizen.
10. Needless red tape and lawsuits delay effective implementation of forest health projects on public lands.
11. The increased density of forests in the West has not damaged ecosystems.
12. The main issue in forest management is to protect loss of life and property due to catastrophic wildfire. 
13. People should take what is needed from forests, but in a context of stewardship and sustainable use and interaction with nature. 
14. Using citizen participation in forest management is very important for basing decisions on different ideas and cultural values along with science. 
15. The government is advancing timber sales in the name of ecological restoration.
16. Without public participation there will be conflict, whereas participation leads to cooperation.
17. We need to experiment with a range of treatments that could meet restoration goals. 
18. Humans are a part of the environment. We need to learn how to live sustainably with that environment as much as possible. 
19. Forest health means jobs.
20. Aggressive fire suppression has caused the majority of the problems regarding  fires. 
21. Environmental organizations have moved the management of our forests to where it is being done by emotion and not by science.
22. Land managers should return public forest land to natural conditions and fire cycles that are specific to each forest-type.
23. Federal agencies need to restore public trust through transparency in project intent, development and implementation.
24. Science is the most important component informing all management decisions — more so than social, cultural and economic considerations.
25. We have to move forward with large-scale restoration-based fuel reduction and learn as we go.
26. Returning forests to presettlement conditions ignores the need for wildlife that are adapted to current forest conditions by mandating drastic thinning virtually overnight. 
27. Small scale thinning projects should give the communities involved pride in taking part in a sustainable forest management plan, and it also allows the traditional communities to realize a boost to their fragile economies.
28. Forest management involves restoring ecosystem function and processes that maintain ecosystems over the long run. 
29. Stakeholders in forest management should work together to define management objectives more by experiments and adaptive management. 
30. Forest health needs restoring after decades of government mismanagement.
31. All fuels treatment projects on public lands should comply with existing environmental laws even if compliance slows implementation.
32. Traditional, sustainable forestry that benefits local economies and maintains rural livelihoods is much better than large scale corporate forestry.
33. Federal forest management policy should make it easier for loggers to thin out backcountry forests by easing regulatory restrictions and making it harder for interest groups to stop or delay that work.
34. Old Growth protection is necessary in order to preserve and protect the viability of species dependent upon Old Growth ecosystems.
35. Prescribed burns are a flawed idea, especially when there are other practices available for restoration.
36. Prescribed burning is needed to restore fire-adapted ecosystems.
37. Fire is a natural and vital component of most western forest ecosystems.
38. To make thinning projects cost effective, private logging companies must be able to log larger trees.
39. Demonizing fire is a mistake: we must accept risks of fire damage to property and implement controlled burning.
40. We need to be cautious: the solution is there, but we still have a lot to learn. If we just jump in, we're going to make mistakes.
41. We need to clean up the bureaucratic maze that stops our professional foresters from being able to do the work that they are trained to do.
42. Forests must contribute to the economic stability of forest-dependent communities.  There are many job opportunities and value-added products that come out of the forest such as wood for art, vigas for building homes, wildlife for food, herbs for medicine, and grass for livestock.
43. Thinning efforts should focus entirely on the small trees that make up the vast majority of the fire risk in the forest. 
44. A diameter cap should be placed on all thinning projects to ensure large trees are not cut.
45. We should not manipulate nature by restoring forest conditions.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Management that favors local-based harvesting for fuel and timber needs.
2. Management that favors treatments to restore structure, function and composition of the forest to presettlement conditions, and allowing the introduction of fire as a natural disturbance.
3. Management that favors thinning treatments to realize economic gain.
4. Management that favors aggressive reduction of hazardous fuels
5. Management that prioritizes the location and level of treatments favoring both ecological and social values (i.e. wildlife, watersheds, community protection, special cultural places).
6. Management that favors the protection of wildlife and wildlife habitat.
7. No fire or fuels management. Leaving the forests as they stand without active management.

- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritized balanced management considering both ecological and social values.

5. People should take what is needed from forests, but in a context of stewardship and sustainable use and interaction with nature. 
6. Stakeholders in forest management should work together to define management objectives more by experiments and adaptive management. 
7. To make thinning projects cost effective, private logging companies must be able to log larger trees.
8. Forests must contribute to the economic stability of forest-dependent communities.  There are many job opportunities and value-added products that come out of the forest such as wood for art, vigas for building homes, wildlife for food, herbs for medicine, and grass for livestock.
9. Aggressive fire suppression has caused the majority of the problems regarding  fires. 
10. The main issue in forest management is to protect loss of life and property due to catastrophic wildfire. 
11. Returning forests to presettlement conditions ignores the need for wildlife that are adapted to current forest conditions by mandating drastic thinning virtually overnight. 
12. Forest health needs restoring after decades of government mismanagement.
13. The increased density of forests in the West has not damaged ecosystems.
14. Fire risk reduction projects should clearly focus on the wildland-urban interface, avoiding treatments in roadless areas.
15. Forest health means jobs.
16. We need to be cautious: the solution is there, but we still have a lot to learn. If we just jump in, we're going to make mistakes.
17. Without public participation there will be conflict, whereas participation leads to cooperation.
18. Small scale thinning projects should give the communities involved pride in taking part in a sustainable forest management plan, and it also allows the traditional communities to realize a boost to their fragile economies.
19. A diameter cap should be placed on all thinning projects to ensure large trees are not cut.
20. Federal forest management policy should make it easier for loggers to thin out backcountry forests by easing regulatory restrictions and making it harder for interest groups to stop or delay that work.
21. All fuels treatment projects on public lands should comply with existing environmental laws even if compliance slows implementation.
22. Using citizen participation in forest management is very important for basing decisions on different ideas and cultural values along with science. 
23. Traditional, sustainable forestry that benefits local economies and maintains rural livelihoods is much better than large scale corporate forestry.
24. The government is advancing timber sales in the name of ecological restoration.
25. Federal land management procedures are so complex that they prevent timely action to address ecological crises on public lands.
26. If an action is determined to be necessary to control a wildfire, save lives and/or property, and ensure that fire crews can do their jobs safely and efficiently, then it is appropriate to act even if it results in the take of an endangered species.
27. We need active forest management on our public lands, through thinning and prescribed burns to reduce the unnatural buildup of fuels.
28. We have to move forward with large-scale restoration-based fuel reduction and learn as we go.
29. We need to allow forest managers to determine how to improve forest health to minimize fire damage and loss.
30. Natural resources must be developed for the benefit of the plain American citizen.
31. Large trees must be removed in order to create openings for wildlife habitat. 
32. We should not manipulate nature by restoring forest conditions.
33. Demonizing fire is a mistake: we must accept risks of fire damage to property and implement controlled burning.
34. Federal agencies need to restore public trust through transparency in project intent, development and implementation.
35. Old Growth protection is necessary in order to preserve and protect the viability of species dependent upon Old Growth ecosystems.
36. Forest restoration projects should be done in all areas of the forest including roadless and wilderness areas.
37. Needless red tape and lawsuits delay effective implementation of forest health projects on public lands.
38. Science is the most important component informing all management decisions — more so than social, cultural and economic considerations.
39. Forest management involves restoring ecosystem function and processes that maintain ecosystems over the long run. 
40. Humans are a part of the environment. We need to learn how to live sustainably with that environment as much as possible. 
41. Thinning efforts should focus entirely on the small trees that make up the vast majority of the fire risk in the forest. 
42. Prescribed burns are a flawed idea, especially when there are other practices available for restoration.
43. Fire is a natural and vital component of most western forest ecosystems.
44. Forest lands should be brought back to their state before human intervention began.
45. We need to experiment with a range of treatments that could meet restoration goals.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Management that favors local-based harvesting for fuel and timber needs.
2. No fire or fuels management. Leaving the forests as they stand without active management.
3. Management that favors the protection of wildlife and wildlife habitat.
4. Management that favors aggressive reduction of hazardous fuels
5. Management that favors treatments to restore structure, function and composition of the forest to presettlement conditions, and allowing the introduction of fire as a natural disturbance.
6. Management that prioritizes the location and level of treatments favoring both ecological and social values (i.e. wildlife, watersheds, community protection, special cultural places).
7. Management that favors thinning treatments to realize economic gain.

- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritized management that balances ecological and social values with restoration and protection.

4. Stakeholders in forest management should work together to define management objectives more by experiments and adaptive management. 
5. Fire is a natural and vital component of most western forest ecosystems.
6. Using citizen participation in forest management is very important for basing decisions on different ideas and cultural values along with science. 
7. Federal agencies need to restore public trust through transparency in project intent, development and implementation.
8. Without public participation there will be conflict, whereas participation leads to cooperation.
9. Environmental organizations have moved the management of our forests to where it is being done by emotion and not by science.
10. We need to clean up the bureaucratic maze that stops our professional foresters from being able to do the work that they are trained to do.
11. We need to be cautious: the solution is there, but we still have a lot to learn. If we just jump in, we're going to make mistakes.
12. All fuels treatment projects on public lands should comply with existing environmental laws even if compliance slows implementation.
13. Forest health means jobs.
14. Fire risk reduction projects should clearly focus on the wildland-urban interface, avoiding treatments in roadless areas.
15. We should not manipulate nature by restoring forest conditions.
16. Humans are a part of the environment. We need to learn how to live sustainably with that environment as much as possible. 
17. Old Growth protection is necessary in order to preserve and protect the viability of species dependent upon Old Growth ecosystems.
18. Federal forest management policy should make it easier for loggers to thin out backcountry forests by easing regulatory restrictions and making it harder for interest groups to stop or delay that work.
19. The main issue in forest management is to protect loss of life and property due to catastrophic wildfire. 
20. The government is advancing timber sales in the name of ecological restoration.
21. Aggressive fire suppression has caused the majority of the problems regarding  fires. 
22. We need to experiment with a range of treatments that could meet restoration goals. 
23. Returning forests to presettlement conditions ignores the need for wildlife that are adapted to current forest conditions by mandating drastic thinning virtually overnight. 
24. We need to allow forest managers to determine how to improve forest health to minimize fire damage and loss.
25. The increased density of forests in the West has not damaged ecosystems.
26. Prescribed burns are a flawed idea, especially when there are other practices available for restoration.
27. Forest management involves restoring ecosystem function and processes that maintain ecosystems over the long run. 
28. A diameter cap should be placed on all thinning projects to ensure large trees are not cut.
29. Natural resources must be developed for the benefit of the plain American citizen.
30. Large trees must be removed in order to create openings for wildlife habitat. 
31. We have to move forward with large-scale restoration-based fuel reduction and learn as we go.
32. Prescribed burning is needed to restore fire-adapted ecosystems.
33. Forest lands should be brought back to their state before human intervention began.
34. Forest restoration projects should be done in all areas of the forest including roadless and wilderness areas.
35. Land managers should return public forest land to natural conditions and fire cycles that are specific to each forest-type.
36. Federal land management procedures are so complex that they prevent timely action to address ecological crises on public lands.
37. If an action is determined to be necessary to control a wildfire, save lives and/or property, and ensure that fire crews can do their jobs safely and efficiently, then it is appropriate to act even if it results in the take of an endangered species.
38. Demonizing fire is a mistake: we must accept risks of fire damage to property and implement controlled burning.
39. We need active forest management on our public lands, through thinning and prescribed burns to reduce the unnatural buildup of fuels.
40. Small scale thinning projects should give the communities involved pride in taking part in a sustainable forest management plan, and it also allows the traditional communities to realize a boost to their fragile economies.
41. Forests must contribute to the economic stability of forest-dependent communities.  There are many job opportunities and value-added products that come out of the forest such as wood for art, vigas for building homes, wildlife for food, herbs for medicine, and grass for livestock.
42. Forest health needs restoring after decades of government mismanagement.
43. Science is the most important component informing all management decisions — more so than social, cultural and economic considerations.
44. Traditional, sustainable forestry that benefits local economies and maintains rural livelihoods is much better than large scale corporate forestry.
45. Needless red tape and lawsuits delay effective implementation of forest health projects on public lands.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Management that favors local-based harvesting for fuel and timber needs.
2. Management that favors aggressive reduction of hazardous fuels
3. Management that prioritizes the location and level of treatments favoring both ecological and social values (i.e. wildlife, watersheds, community protection, special cultural places).
4. No fire or fuels management. Leaving the forests as they stand without active management.
5. Management that favors thinning treatments to realize economic gain.
6. Management that favors treatments to restore structure, function and composition of the forest to presettlement conditions, and allowing the introduction of fire as a natural disturbance.
7. Management that favors the protection of wildlife and wildlife habitat.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritized balanced management considering ecological and social values.

3. If an action is determined to be necessary to control a wildfire, save lives and/or property, and ensure that fire crews can do their jobs safely and efficiently, then it is appropriate to act even if it results in the take of an endangered species.
4. To make thinning projects cost effective, private logging companies must be able to log larger trees.
5. Environmental organizations have moved the management of our forests to where it is being done by emotion and not by science.
6. We need to allow forest managers to determine how to improve forest health to minimize fire damage and loss.
7. We should not manipulate nature by restoring forest conditions.
8. Humans are a part of the environment. We need to learn how to live sustainably with that environment as much as possible. 
9. Forest health needs restoring after decades of government mismanagement.
10. Needless red tape and lawsuits delay effective implementation of forest health projects on public lands.
11. Stakeholders in forest management should work together to define management objectives more by experiments and adaptive management. 
12. Forest restoration projects should be done in all areas of the forest including roadless and wilderness areas.
13. People should take what is needed from forests, but in a context of stewardship and sustainable use and interaction with nature. 
14. We need active forest management on our public lands, through thinning and prescribed burns to reduce the unnatural buildup of fuels.
15. Returning forests to presettlement conditions ignores the need for wildlife that are adapted to current forest conditions by mandating drastic thinning virtually overnight. 
16. Federal land management procedures are so complex that they prevent timely action to address ecological crises on public lands.
17. The government is advancing timber sales in the name of ecological restoration.
18. Traditional, sustainable forestry that benefits local economies and maintains rural livelihoods is much better than large scale corporate forestry.
19. Federal agencies need to restore public trust through transparency in project intent, development and implementation.
20. Science is the most important component informing all management decisions — more so than social, cultural and economic considerations.
21. Aggressive fire suppression has caused the majority of the problems regarding  fires. 
22. The increased density of forests in the West has not damaged ecosystems.
23. Large trees must be removed in order to create openings for wildlife habitat. 
24. Using citizen participation in forest management is very important for basing decisions on different ideas and cultural values along with science. 
25. Federal forest management policy should make it easier for loggers to thin out backcountry forests by easing regulatory restrictions and making it harder for interest groups to stop or delay that work.
26. Thinning efforts should focus entirely on the small trees that make up the vast majority of the fire risk in the forest. 
27. Land managers should return public forest land to natural conditions and fire cycles that are specific to each forest-type.
28. Fire risk reduction projects should clearly focus on the wildland-urban interface, avoiding treatments in roadless areas.
29. All fuels treatment projects on public lands should comply with existing environmental laws even if compliance slows implementation.
30. Natural resources must be developed for the benefit of the plain American citizen.
31. Prescribed burns are a flawed idea, especially when there are other practices available for restoration.
32. Prescribed burning is needed to restore fire-adapted ecosystems.
33. Forest management involves restoring ecosystem function and processes that maintain ecosystems over the long run. 
34. Small scale thinning projects should give the communities involved pride in taking part in a sustainable forest management plan, and it also allows the traditional communities to realize a boost to their fragile economies.
35. The main issue in forest management is to protect loss of life and property due to catastrophic wildfire. 
36. A diameter cap should be placed on all thinning projects to ensure large trees are not cut.
37. Forest health means jobs.
38. We need to be cautious: the solution is there, but we still have a lot to learn. If we just jump in, we're going to make mistakes.
39. Without public participation there will be conflict, whereas participation leads to cooperation.
40. Forests must contribute to the economic stability of forest-dependent communities.  There are many job opportunities and value-added products that come out of the forest such as wood for art, vigas for building homes, wildlife for food, herbs for medicine, and grass for livestock.
41. We have to move forward with large-scale restoration-based fuel reduction and learn as we go.
42. Forest lands should be brought back to their state before human intervention began.
43. Old Growth protection is necessary in order to preserve and protect the viability of species dependent upon Old Growth ecosystems.
44. Fire is a natural and vital component of most western forest ecosystems.
45. Demonizing fire is a mistake: we must accept risks of fire damage to property and implement controlled burning.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Management that favors the protection of wildlife and wildlife habitat.
2. Management that favors treatments to restore structure, function and composition of the forest to presettlement conditions, and allowing the introduction of fire as a natural disturbance.
3. Management that favors thinning treatments to realize economic gain.
4. No fire or fuels management. Leaving the forests as they stand without active management.
5. Management that prioritizes the location and level of treatments favoring both ecological and social values (i.e. wildlife, watersheds, community protection, special cultural places).
6. Management that favors local-based harvesting for fuel and timber needs.
7. Management that favors aggressive reduction of hazardous fuels

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritized balanced management that considers both ecological and social values.
