2. Using citizen participation in forest management is very important for basing decisions on different ideas and cultural values along with science. 
3. Prescribed burns are a flawed idea, especially when there are other practices available for restoration.
4. Prescribed burning is needed to restore fire-adapted ecosystems.
5. Forest health needs restoring after decades of government mismanagement.
6. Needless red tape and lawsuits delay effective implementation of forest health projects on public lands.
7. Federal agencies need to restore public trust through transparency in project intent, development and implementation.
8. Forest lands should be brought back to their state before human intervention began.
9. Science is the most important component informing all management decisions — more so than social, cultural and economic considerations.
10. Stakeholders in forest management should work together to define management objectives more by experiments and adaptive management. 
11. Forests must contribute to the economic stability of forest-dependent communities.  There are many job opportunities and value-added products that come out of the forest such as wood for art, vigas for building homes, wildlife for food, herbs for medicine, and grass for livestock.
12. Humans are a part of the environment. We need to learn how to live sustainably with that environment as much as possible. 
13. We need active forest management on our public lands, through thinning and prescribed burns to reduce the unnatural buildup of fuels.
14. Forest management involves restoring ecosystem function and processes that maintain ecosystems over the long run. 
15. Forest health means jobs.
16. Returning forests to presettlement conditions ignores the need for wildlife that are adapted to current forest conditions by mandating drastic thinning virtually overnight. 
17. We need to clean up the bureaucratic maze that stops our professional foresters from being able to do the work that they are trained to do.
18. Natural resources must be developed for the benefit of the plain American citizen.
19. Without public participation there will be conflict, whereas participation leads to cooperation.
20. Small scale thinning projects should give the communities involved pride in taking part in a sustainable forest management plan, and it also allows the traditional communities to realize a boost to their fragile economies.
21. We have to move forward with large-scale restoration-based fuel reduction and learn as we go.
22. Thinning efforts should focus entirely on the small trees that make up the vast majority of the fire risk in the forest. 
23. Aggressive fire suppression has caused the majority of the problems regarding  fires. 
24. Environmental organizations have moved the management of our forests to where it is being done by emotion and not by science.
25. Land managers should return public forest land to natural conditions and fire cycles that are specific to each forest-type.
26. A diameter cap should be placed on all thinning projects to ensure large trees are not cut.
27. We need to experiment with a range of treatments that could meet restoration goals. 
28. Large trees must be removed in order to create openings for wildlife habitat. 
29. Forest restoration projects should be done in all areas of the forest including roadless and wilderness areas.
30. Demonizing fire is a mistake: we must accept risks of fire damage to property and implement controlled burning.
31. Old Growth protection is necessary in order to preserve and protect the viability of species dependent upon Old Growth ecosystems.
32. People should take what is needed from forests, but in a context of stewardship and sustainable use and interaction with nature. 
33. We need to allow forest managers to determine how to improve forest health to minimize fire damage and loss.
34. Federal forest management policy should make it easier for loggers to thin out backcountry forests by easing regulatory restrictions and making it harder for interest groups to stop or delay that work.
35. We need to be cautious: the solution is there, but we still have a lot to learn. If we just jump in, we're going to make mistakes.
36. Federal land management procedures are so complex that they prevent timely action to address ecological crises on public lands.
37. All fuels treatment projects on public lands should comply with existing environmental laws even if compliance slows implementation.
38. The increased density of forests in the West has not damaged ecosystems.
39. To make thinning projects cost effective, private logging companies must be able to log larger trees.
40. Fire is a natural and vital component of most western forest ecosystems.
41. Fire risk reduction projects should clearly focus on the wildland-urban interface, avoiding treatments in roadless areas.
42. The government is advancing timber sales in the name of ecological restoration.
43. We should not manipulate nature by restoring forest conditions.
44. Traditional, sustainable forestry that benefits local economies and maintains rural livelihoods is much better than large scale corporate forestry.
45. If an action is determined to be necessary to control a wildfire, save lives and/or property, and ensure that fire crews can do their jobs safely and efficiently, then it is appropriate to act even if it results in the take of an endangered species.

3. 3

## [Policies]:
1. Management that favors local-based harvesting for fuel and timber needs.
2. Management that favors treatments to restore structure, function and composition of the forest to presettlement conditions, and allowing the introduction of fire as a natural disturbance.
3. No fire or fuels management. Leaving the forests as they stand without active management.
4. Management that prioritizes the location and level of treatments favoring both ecological and social values (i.e. wildlife, watersheds, community protection, special cultural places).
5. Management that favors the protection of wildlife and wildlife habitat.
6. Management that favors aggressive reduction of hazardous fuels
7. Management that favors thinning treatments to realize economic gain.

## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 38 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 38 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 38 lines in total.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. The fact that we cannot predict what biobanks will be used for bothers me. 
2. Participants who donate their samples for research should be given special access to the treatments and therapies that result from that research. 
3. Genetic information is different from health information. 
4. I trust researchers to control access to my personal samples.
5. Scientists should have access to all unidentified, personal samples for research.
6. If someone is a carrier of a genetic disease, they have a responsibility to participate in genetic research.
7. Biobanks need independent review boards to determine who should have access to samples. 
8. The priority for healthcare should be to reduce inequalities and the burden of disease.
9. Deciding how to regulate biobanks should be left to the government. 
10. Genetic studies of disability will lead to the discrimination of people living with the same conditions.
11. Race is a useful topic for genetic studies.
12. Profits from biobanking should be returned to the donating community. 
13. Biobanks are useful even if they only produce more scientific knowledge and not medical advancements.
14. To me, religious communities need to be consulted about genetic and biobank research. 
15. There is no point in consulting the public about ethical issues in science and technology.
16. The community that donates samples for research should receive improved medical services.  
17. I do not care if my donated sample is connected to my name and medical information.
18. I should have property rights to my tissues before or after they leave my body.
19. Participants should be contacted every time researchers want to use their samples for research.
20. Biobanks will only lead to expensive treatments and high profits. 
21. Permission from the indigenous community must be sought if samples are collected from indigenous peoples.
22. Aboriginal communities require special consideration concerning healthcare and research.
23. There is no risk to the participants who donate to biobanks.
24. Public funds should pay for biobanks, instead of private companies.  
25. All participants should be paid for donating their samples to a biobank. 
26. Educating people about health issues (e.g. diet and lifestyle changes) promises greater health effects than investing in biobanks.
27. The confidentiality of personal medical information is critical in any circumstance where research is being conducted.
28. Researchers should be allowed to use samples for research but they should not own them.  
29. Genetic research will improve our lives.
30. It is always permissible to do research on my personally identifiable sample without my prior permission.  
31. Policy makers should consider the possibility that Canada should not pursue biobanking.
32. Genetic studies of race on enthocultural communities will lead to the discrimination of those same enthocultural communities. 
33. Participants should be active in the set up and oversight of  biobanks. 
34. High-priced genetic research is diverting funds that could be used to promote public health.
35. My personal sample should never be anonymized since I should be informed of important research results.  
36. Sampling some people in an ethnocultural community is acceptable only if the whole ethnocultural community has agreed to participate.
37. Participants should always be able to withdraw their sample from research at anytime. 
38. Everyone should donate samples to a biobank for the benefit of everyone.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires approval by an appropriate governing body (e.g., research ethics board), regardless of whether the individual is identifiable.
2. Every use of stored data and biological samples for research requires the authorization of individuals, even if the use does not identify the individual.
3. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires approval by an appropriate governing body (e.g., research ethics board), ONLY when the individual is identifiable.
4. Regardless of privacy and oversight, it is most important to ensure benefits to society or the community (e.g., geographical, ethno-cultural) participating in a collection of data and biological samples.
5. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires authorization from individuals only when they are identifiable AND approval by an appropriate governing body (e.g. research ethics board) when they are not identifiable.
6. Regardless of privacy and oversight, it is most important to prevent discrimination (e.g., through insurance, social attitudes) that might result from research on collections of data and biological samples.
7. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires authorization from individuals ONLY when the individual is identifiable.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritizing governing body approval and individual authorization ensures responsible use of data and samples.

1. To give subsidies only to farmers who do not use pesticides is an "extreme" approach that would mean falling crop yields and higher food prices
2. I think it is safe to say climate change is here.
3. Food waste is a major environmental issue
4. I am happy to buy fairtrade products, like chocolate or coffee, even if they are of lower quality
5. If Switzerland implements strong regulations on importing environmentally-sustainable and fairly-produced food, we would either have to step out of our international trade agreements or have to renegotiate most of them
6. The government should apply costum duties on imported products that can be produced in Switzerland (e.g., cheese, honey, apples, beef)
7. Climate warming will ultimately benefit food production globally as plants better growth in higher temperature
8. It is essential to always have fresh products available to be prepared for any situation (e.g. unexpected guests)

12. I am happy to change my nutrition habits, as use leftovers in future meals, if this helps to prevent food waste
13. Biodiversity is at risk due to the use of pesticides and monoculture farming
14. Banning pesticides might help the local biodiversity but decreases our food production capacity and autonomy
15. Restaurants in schools or retirement homes should only offer vegetarian menus.
16. Farmers should be encouraged to practice ecologically sustainable agriculture, such as permaculture.
17. I am happy to pay a higher price for local or organic food products
18. Food waste is an important social issue (e.g. hunger in the world)
19. Eating sustainably is too expensive, and only wealthy people can afford it
20. Intensive animal farming and monocultural plantation guarantees food supply
21. We should introduce taxes to prevent food waste
22. Strong regulation of food products will eventually damage our economic relationship with other countries
23. I don't care where the product I am buying comes from.
24. Extreme weather disasters affect global food availability
25. The government should ensure that farmers are paid fair prices for their produce to secure higher incomes for those working in agriculture
26. Products that employ products that damage the environment, such as palm oil, should be taxed in a similar fashion to tobacco products
27. Subsidies should only be given to farmers that do not use pesticides or antibiotics
28. Food thrown away is natural and biodegradable and thus not an issue for the environment
29. Switzerland already has some of the toughest regulations about protecting our environment and agriculture
30. In Switzerland, packaging waste is a greater environmental issue than food thrown away

1. Political measures that create incentives for local producers to produce sustainable foods (e.g., subsidies or tax breaks for local farmers who produce organic products).

3. Political measures that include radical regulation toward sustainable food production (e.g., banning all pesticides, banning the import of foods produced using unsustainable methods).
4. Political measures aimed at investing in research to develop sustainable agricultural techniques or materials.
5. Political measures that focus on less regulation  (e.g., policies that promote free trade agreements by reducing food regulations)
6. Leave the policy settings as they are.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritized policies promoting sustainable food production and local farming over deregulation and inaction.

- Rate each of the 30 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 30 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 30 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Climate warming will ultimately benefit food production globally as plants better growth in higher temperature
2. I don't care where the product I am buying comes from.
3. We should introduce taxes to prevent food waste
4. Climate variation is normal, so why should this be a problem?
5. Farmers should be encouraged to practice ecologically sustainable agriculture, such as permaculture.
6. Food that is NOT environmentally-sustainable, healthy and fairly-produced should be clearly labelled
7. In Switzerland, packaging waste is a greater environmental issue than food thrown away
8. Food waste is a major environmental issue
9. I am happy to change my nutrition habits, as use leftovers in future meals, if this helps to prevent food waste
10. Food thrown away is natural and biodegradable and thus not an issue for the environment
11. Eating sustainably is too expensive, and only wealthy people can afford it
12. Switzerland already has some of the toughest regulations about protecting our environment and agriculture
13. Intensive animal farming and monocultural plantation guarantees food supply
14. Subsidies should only be given to farmers that do not use pesticides or antibiotics
15. If Switzerland implements strong regulations on importing environmentally-sustainable and fairly-produced food, we would either have to step out of our international trade agreements or have to renegotiate most of them
16. Products that employ products that damage the environment, such as palm oil, should be taxed in a similar fashion to tobacco products
17. Extreme weather disasters affect global food availability
18. I am happy to pay a higher price for local or organic food products
19. Strong regulation of food products will eventually damage our economic relationship with other countries
20. Biodiversity is at risk due to the use of pesticides and monoculture farming
21. Restaurants in schools or retirement homes should only offer vegetarian menus.
22. It is essential to always have fresh products available to be prepared for any situation (e.g. unexpected guests)
23. The government should apply costum duties on imported products that can be produced in Switzerland (e.g., cheese, honey, apples, beef)
24. Food waste is an important social issue (e.g. hunger in the world)
25. Animal antibiotical resistance will be the source of the next global pandemic
26. I am happy to buy fairtrade products, like chocolate or coffee, even if they are of lower quality
27. I think it is safe to say climate change is here.
28. The government should ensure that farmers are paid fair prices for their produce to secure higher incomes for those working in agriculture
29. To give subsidies only to farmers who do not use pesticides is an "extreme" approach that would mean falling crop yields and higher food prices
30. Banning pesticides might help the local biodiversity but decreases our food production capacity and autonomy

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 6 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 6, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 6 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 6 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 6 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Political measures that focus on less regulation  (e.g., policies that promote free trade agreements by reducing food regulations)
2. Political measures that include moderate regulation toward sustainable food production (e.g., banning certain pesticides, providing incentives for organic farming).
3. Political measures aimed at investing in research to develop sustainable agricultural techniques or materials.
4. Leave the policy settings as they are.
5. Political measures that include radical regulation toward sustainable food production (e.g., banning all pesticides, banning the import of foods produced using unsustainable methods).
6. Political measures that create incentives for local producers to produce sustainable foods (e.g., subsidies or tax breaks for local farmers who produce organic products).

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritized policies promoting sustainability and environmental protection while supporting local producers.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 32 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 32 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 32 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. There is no urgent need to prepare for an increase in illnesses and deaths caused by high temperatures.
2. It is necessary to have strong on-the-ground disaster response capabilities to deal with extreme weather conditions.
3. There is not enough information to conclusively say that climate change is real.
4. We need to take into account the negative effects of climate change on local businesses.
5. It is important to support vulnerable groups (the elderly, children, people with disabilities, low-income individuals) as they have fewer resources to deal with the impacts of climate change.
6. It is difficult to trust scientists' reports on climate change.
7. Even if Switzerland were to reduce all its CO₂ emissions, global warming would continue.
8. Authorities should receive additional funding to strengthen measures against emergencies and weather-related disasters such as floods.
9. I don't know what to do. I am very worried and would like to do something, but I don't have a realistic set of actions that would truly make a difference.
10. The urban heat island effect must be tackled with measures such as planting trees.
11. It is difficult to trust government reports on climate change.
12. Switzerland is particularly vulnerable to climate change, and it is in our interest to contribute to an effective global solution.
13. It is important to focus on adaptation measures that take into account the country's economic future.
14. It is difficult to trust what the media report about climate change.
15. It is NOT necessary to involve society in deciding which key issues are important for climate change adaptation planning.
16. Health systems must prepare for both the physical health impacts of climate change (e.g., heat stroke) and the mental health impacts (e.g., farmers losing their crops).
17. Planning climate change response measures requires a global approach that considers a wide range of interventions rather than specific individual actions.
18. The planning of measures to tackle climate change should focus primarily on extreme weather events such as droughts and floods.
19. Authorities have the resources they need to effectively adapt to climate change.
20. Rising insurance costs are a serious problem related to climate change.
21. Society should be included in the discussion on climate change adaptation.
22. Climate change is natural; there is no need to worry.
23. Climate change is primarily caused by human activity.
24. Doing something to reduce emissions seems a bit hopeless to me, but I just want to feel like I'm doing my best.
25. We should focus on protecting human systems rather than protecting ecosystems.
26. It is certain to say that climate change exists.
27. Some countries or regions of the world will be more affected by climate change than others, but this is not our top priority.
28. It doesn't make much sense for me to do anything to solve the problem. No one else is doing anything.
29. It is important to prepare for the migration of people displaced by the effects of climate change.
30. I believe that the impact we can achieve as individuals in Switzerland is so small that our actions are useless.
31. The melting of Alpine glaciers is not a real problem for our daily lives.
32. I'm not going to do anything about climate change because it's not an important issue.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Preparing for climate risk through the development of new approaches and technologies that enhance resilience to the impacts of climate variability or change.
2. Adaptation policies and expenditure. Planning controls and emergency response programs.
3. Policies that emphasise economic growth over climate change adaptation or mitigation.
4. "Policies that involve a moderate reduction in CO₂ emissions (e.g., reducing emissions by 25% to 50% over the next 10 years)."
5. "Policies that involve a radical reduction in CO₂ emissions (e.g., reducing emissions by 50% to 100% over the next 10 years)."
6. Adaptation policies that target individual, small business or community-based actions (e.g., support the installation of alternative energy generators, insulation, water use efficiency)
7. Leave the policy settings as they are.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritizing adaptation policies and resilience over economic growth and inaction.

2. Some countries or regions of the world will be more affected by climate change than others, but this is not our top priority.
3. We need to take into account the negative effects of climate change on local businesses.
4. Health systems must prepare for both the physical health impacts of climate change (e.g., heat stroke) and the mental health impacts (e.g., farmers losing their crops).
5. It is important to support vulnerable groups (the elderly, children, people with disabilities, low-income individuals) as they have fewer resources to deal with the impacts of climate change.
6. Doing something to reduce emissions seems a bit hopeless to me, but I just want to feel like I'm doing my best.
7. It is NOT necessary to involve society in deciding which key issues are important for climate change adaptation planning.
8. It is difficult to trust what the media report about climate change.
9. Climate change is natural; there is no need to worry.
10. Authorities should receive additional funding to strengthen measures against emergencies and weather-related disasters such as floods.
11. It is important to focus on adaptation measures that take into account the country's economic future.
12. It doesn't make much sense for me to do anything to solve the problem. No one else is doing anything.
13. Society should be included in the discussion on climate change adaptation.
14. The urban heat island effect must be tackled with measures such as planting trees.
15. The planning of measures to tackle climate change should focus primarily on extreme weather events such as droughts and floods.
16. I'm not going to do anything about climate change because it's not an important issue.
17. Switzerland is particularly vulnerable to climate change, and it is in our interest to contribute to an effective global solution.
18. It is important to prepare for the migration of people displaced by the effects of climate change.
19. I believe that the impact we can achieve as individuals in Switzerland is so small that our actions are useless.
20. I don't know what to do. I am very worried and would like to do something, but I don't have a realistic set of actions that would truly make a difference.
21. Authorities have the resources they need to effectively adapt to climate change.
22. Even if Switzerland were to reduce all its CO₂ emissions, global warming would continue.
23. Planning climate change response measures requires a global approach that considers a wide range of interventions rather than specific individual actions.
24. It is difficult to trust scientists' reports on climate change.
25. Rising insurance costs are a serious problem related to climate change.
26. We should focus on protecting human systems rather than protecting ecosystems.
27. It is difficult to trust government reports on climate change.
28. There is not enough information to conclusively say that climate change is real.
29. The melting of Alpine glaciers is not a real problem for our daily lives.
30. There is no urgent need to prepare for an increase in illnesses and deaths caused by high temperatures.
31. It is necessary to have strong on-the-ground disaster response capabilities to deal with extreme weather conditions.
32. It is certain to say that climate change exists.

## [Considerations]:
1. Climate fluctuations are normal and do not pose a problem for humans.
2. I believe that the impact we can achieve as individuals in Switzerland is so small that our actions are useless.
3. Society should be included in the discussion on climate change adaptation.
4. I don't know what to do. I am very worried and would like to do something, but I don't have a realistic set of actions that would truly make a difference.
5. Switzerland is particularly vulnerable to climate change, and it is in our interest to contribute to an effective global solution.
6. There is no urgent need to prepare for an increase in illnesses and deaths caused by high temperatures.
7. It is NOT necessary to involve society in deciding which key issues are important for climate change adaptation planning.
8. Doing something to reduce emissions seems a bit hopeless to me, but I just want to feel like I'm doing my best.
9. If Switzerland reduces its greenhouse gas emissions, it won't make any difference.
10. Municipalities have sufficient resources to effectively adapt to climate change.
11. It is important to focus on adaptation measures that take into account the country's economic future.
12. We need to take into account the negative effects of climate change on local businesses.
13. Climate change adaptation planning requires a holistic approach that considers a wide range of areas rather than focusing on individual issues.
14. Climate change is mainly caused by human activities.
15. It is difficult to trust what the media report about climate change.
16. Some groups will be more affected by climate change than others, but this is not a priority issue.
17. It is difficult to trust scientists' reports on climate change.
18. Further (local) funding is needed to strengthen our emergency response to events such as floods.
19. The climate threat to alpine glaciers is too distant from local issues to be of concern in the Canton Aargau.
20. It is certain that climate change exists.
21. It is necessary to have strong on-the-ground disaster response capabilities to deal with extreme weather conditions.
22. Health systems must prepare for both the physical health impacts of climate change (e.g., heat stroke) and the mental health impacts (e.g., farmers losing their crops).
23. It doesn't make much sense for me to do anything to solve the problem. No one else is doing anything.
24. The urban heat island effect must be tackled with measures such as planting trees.
25. Biodiversity is declining worldwide.
26. Rising insurance costs are a serious problem related to climate change.
27. There is not enough information to conclusively say that climate change is real.
28. I'm not going to do anything about climate change because it's not an important issue.
29. We should focus on protecting human systems rather than protecting ecosystems.
30. It is important to prepare for the migration of people displaced by the effects of climate change.
31. It is important to support vulnerable groups (the elderly, children, people with disabilities, low-income individuals) as they have fewer resources to deal with the impacts of climate change.
32. The main goal of climate change adaptation planning should be preparing for extreme weather events such as droughts and floods.
33. It is difficult to trust government reports on climate change.

## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 36 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- Using the Q Methodology, rate the statements following a Fixed Quasi-Normal Distribution between 1 and 11.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 36 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 36 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. This magnificent timber bridge is a rare and beautiful sight in today's world, it should be preserved. 
2. Any changes to the bridge should give right consideration to the environment.bridge
3. The bridge has stood the test of time for the past 67 years; there's no need for major changes to it.
4. The most important thing is that access to Fremantle from its north is maintained in the most undisturbed manner as possible. 
5. There are no specific economic benefits for the Fremantle from the bridge.
6. It is worth spending money to retain the iconic status of the bridge.
7. The old bridge provides a scenic entrance to Fremantle that attracts tourists.
8. River craft deserve better traffic conditions on the Swan River.
9. Since the traffic bridge has important heritage significance, the only grounds for its removal should be on the grounds of serious safety issues and verified by heritage engineers.
10. Tax payers money should be spent on services that are more essential than upgrading the bridge.
11. We should definitely preserve the heritage value of the bridge, but only if it is financially viable.
12. The problem is not the vulnerable structure of the bridge but excessive traffic, which should be reduced.
13. When deciding about the future of the bridge, indigenous concerns should be given adequate consideration. 
14. As long as there is a bridge that I can cross, I don't care about its structure.
15. The most important issue for cyclists is safety, which means they need access across the bridge which has a good surface.
16. We shouldn't stick to the past when deciding about the future of the bridge, we should be open for modern design options.
17. The bridge is certainly an attractive entry statement to Fremantle and without doubt far more important than trucks.
18. Altering or replacing the existing Fremantle Bridge means diminishing Fremantle.
19. Replacing timber elements with steel components would destroy the authentic appearance of the bridge.
20. The critical infrastructure of the bridge raises serious safety concerns. 
21. The Fremantle Bridge is irreplaceable. It is a strong, enduring part of our history.
22. Safe and efficient movement of all road and river users across and under the bridge should the main considerations
23. It is most important that the solution is a long term one.
24. The main concern is to have a bridge that underpins the economic activities in the region.
25. Providing a better pedestrian and cycle traffic should be the main consideration when deciding about the future of the bridge.
26. Whatever works are undertaken, the heritage value of the old bridge will be affected.
27. The Fremantle Traffic Bridge is the most iconic landmark and the main tourist attraction in Fremantle. 
28. The cost of maintaining the old timber structure is too high.
29. The function of the Fremantle Bridge as a transport gateway is more important than its heritage.
30. We just got traffic calming in Town Centre after 25 years effort. I don't want bridge to be build bigger, better faster to reverse the gains of the last 25 years.
31. The safety of the bridge is more important than its appearance.
32. The old bridge will never be able to handle vehicles, bike and pedestrians at the same time.
33. Alterations will lead to nothing but the uglification of the bridge.
34. Reducing the risk of vessel collision on the Swan River should be the main consideration when deciding about the future of the bridge
35. Indigenous people would want to minimize impact on the Swan River, a registered site, that is of importance and significance to them.
36. The existing bridge is too low; archways too narrow and do not line up with the railway bridge making navigation dangerous.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 6 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 6, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 6 the option you support the least.

2. 1
3. 3

## [Policies]:
1. Retain existing bridge, but replace the navigation spans and deteriorated components
2. Construct a new two lane standard bridge and retain the existing bridge as a 2 lane bridge with improved pedestrian/cyclist facilities
3. Retain existing bridge, but replace the navigation spans and deteriorated components and incorporate bridge widening
4. Construct a new bridge that is a major entry statements for Fremantle, leaving a section of the existing bridge as a heritage recreation site
5. Construct a new standard bridge next to the current bridge, leaving a section of the existing bridge as a heritage and recreation site
6. Construct a new standard bridge and retain the existing bridge as a pedestrian/cyclist facility

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 20 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 20 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 20 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Private mental health services are better than public ones, so Switzerland's mental health system should be entirely privatized.
2. Being poor, living far from urban centers, or being a victim of racism are examples of factors that can influence a person's willingness to seek help for mental health problems.
3. Focusing on prevention strategies (e.g., government media campaigns) is essential to reducing the impact of stigma associated with mental health conditions.
4. Improving working or study conditions does not impact people's mental health in any way.
5. Schools should play a crucial role in creating a supportive environment, both online and offline, to mitigate the negative impact of social media on mental health.
6. Individuals should take responsibility for their own mental well-being.
7. Personal cultural or religious beliefs and preferences should guide the choice of treatment methods, including therapy and medication.
8. More government funding is needed to improve mental health services and their accessibility, especially for marginalized people subject to socioeconomic disparities.
9. People with mental disorders should not be allowed to work with children.
10. Mental health issues require less urgency and fewer resources compared to physical health conditions.
11. Personal solutions (such as joining a yoga club) are more effective than government intervention in addressing mental health issues (such as having social workers or psychologists in schools).
12. It is good that basic health insurance does not fully cover mental health care since only a few people need it.
13. People should take responsibility for actively addressing their own biases and prejudices against individuals with mental health disorders.
14. Mental health problems are solely medical in nature and not a social issue.
15. Mental health can be understood in different ways. A comprehensive definition of mental health should take into account social issues such as poverty, inequality, and discrimination.
16. Investing in mental health services in schools and workplaces (for example, having social workers in facilities) is essential to prevent negative mental health outcomes.
17. Minors under the age of 16 should be legally prohibited from using social media.
18. Social media platforms should be required to have parental controls.
19. Social media contribute to mental health issues through cyberbullying, social comparison, and unrealistic portrayals of life.
20. To prevent people with mental health issues from feeling lonely or isolated, we should talk more about these topics in schools and workplaces to increase public understanding and sensitivity.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Private mental health clinics should receive more government funding to allow more people to access them.
2. There are not enough mental health services in Switzerland, so their funding should be increased.
3. There are enough mental health services in Switzerland, and funding should remain as it is.
4. There are too many mental health services in Switzerland, and they should be reduced.
5. There should be more public awareness campaigns that empower people to seek mental health support and destigmatize help-seeking behaviors.
6. Initiatives focused on improving the socioeconomic conditions of disadvantaged people should be implemented to address mental health disparities.
7. There should be more integrated mental health clinics that provide a range of services, such as sports or artistic activities in addition to therapy and medication

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritized policies addressing socioeconomic disparities and increasing funding for mental health services.

- Rate each of the 20 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 20 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 20 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Improving working or study conditions does not impact people's mental health in any way.
2. Private mental health services are better than public ones, so Switzerland's mental health system should be entirely privatized.
3. Minors under the age of 16 should be legally prohibited from using social media.
4. Mental health issues require less urgency and fewer resources compared to physical health conditions.
5. People should take responsibility for actively addressing their own biases and prejudices against individuals with mental health disorders.
6. Social media contribute to mental health issues through cyberbullying, social comparison, and unrealistic portrayals of life.
7. It is good that basic health insurance does not fully cover mental health care since only a few people need it.
8. Focusing on prevention strategies (e.g., government media campaigns) is essential to reducing the impact of stigma associated with mental health conditions.
9. Investing in mental health services in schools and workplaces (for example, having social workers in facilities) is essential to prevent negative mental health outcomes.
10. More government funding is needed to improve mental health services and their accessibility, especially for marginalized people subject to socioeconomic disparities.
11. Social media platforms should be required to have parental controls.
12. To prevent people with mental health issues from feeling lonely or isolated, we should talk more about these topics in schools and workplaces to increase public understanding and sensitivity.
13. Being poor, living far from urban centers, or being a victim of racism are examples of factors that can influence a person's willingness to seek help for mental health problems.
14. Personal cultural or religious beliefs and preferences should guide the choice of treatment methods, including therapy and medication.
15. Mental health problems are solely medical in nature and not a social issue.
16. Individuals should take responsibility for their own mental well-being.
17. People with mental disorders should not be allowed to work with children.
18. Personal solutions (such as joining a yoga club) are more effective than government intervention in addressing mental health issues (such as having social workers or psychologists in schools).
19. Schools should play a crucial role in creating a supportive environment, both online and offline, to mitigate the negative impact of social media on mental health.
20. Mental health can be understood in different ways. A comprehensive definition of mental health should take into account social issues such as poverty, inequality, and discrimination.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Private mental health clinics should receive more government funding to allow more people to access them.
2. There are not enough mental health services in Switzerland, so their funding should be increased.
3. Initiatives focused on improving the socioeconomic conditions of disadvantaged people should be implemented to address mental health disparities.
4. There should be more public awareness campaigns that empower people to seek mental health support and destigmatize help-seeking behaviors.
5. There should be more integrated mental health clinics that provide a range of services, such as sports or artistic activities in addition to therapy and medication
6. There are too many mental health services in Switzerland, and they should be reduced.
7. There are enough mental health services in Switzerland, and funding should remain as it is.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritized policies addressing socioeconomic disparities and increasing mental health services and awareness.

- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. There should be more integrated mental health clinics that provide a range of services, such as sports or artistic activities in addition to therapy and medication
2. Initiatives focused on improving the socioeconomic conditions of disadvantaged people should be implemented to address mental health disparities.
3. There are too many mental health services in Switzerland, and they should be reduced.
4. There should be more public awareness campaigns that empower people to seek mental health support and destigmatize help-seeking behaviors.
5. There are not enough mental health services in Switzerland, so their funding should be increased.
6. There are enough mental health services in Switzerland, and funding should remain as it is.
7. Private mental health clinics should receive more government funding to allow more people to access them.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritized policies addressing socioeconomic disparities and increasing accessibility to mental health services.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 20 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 20 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 20 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Personal solutions (such as joining a yoga club) are more effective than government intervention in addressing mental health issues (such as having social workers or psychologists in schools).
2. Schools should play a crucial role in creating a supportive environment, both online and offline, to mitigate the negative impact of social media on mental health.
3. More government funding is needed to improve mental health services and their accessibility, especially for marginalized people subject to socioeconomic disparities.
4. Being poor, living far from urban centers, or being a victim of racism are examples of factors that can influence a person's willingness to seek help for mental health problems.
5. People with mental disorders should not be allowed to work with children.
6. Personal cultural or religious beliefs and preferences should guide the choice of treatment methods, including therapy and medication.
7. Private mental health services are better than public ones, so Switzerland's mental health system should be entirely privatized.
8. Improving working or study conditions does not impact people's mental health in any way.
9. Social media contribute to mental health issues through cyberbullying, social comparison, and unrealistic portrayals of life.
10. Mental health issues require less urgency and fewer resources compared to physical health conditions.
11. People should take responsibility for actively addressing their own biases and prejudices against individuals with mental health disorders.
12. Mental health problems are solely medical in nature and not a social issue.
13. Individuals should take responsibility for their own mental well-being.
14. It is good that basic health insurance does not fully cover mental health care since only a few people need it.
15. Social media platforms should be required to have parental controls.
16. Mental health can be understood in different ways. A comprehensive definition of mental health should take into account social issues such as poverty, inequality, and discrimination.
17. Investing in mental health services in schools and workplaces (for example, having social workers in facilities) is essential to prevent negative mental health outcomes.
18. Focusing on prevention strategies (e.g., government media campaigns) is essential to reducing the impact of stigma associated with mental health conditions.
19. Minors under the age of 16 should be legally prohibited from using social media.
20. To prevent people with mental health issues from feeling lonely or isolated, we should talk more about these topics in schools and workplaces to increase public understanding and sensitivity.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 43 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 43 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 43 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. It's difficult to trust what comes out in the media on the issue of climate change.
2. “Food accessibility (price) and security (availability) is NOT COMPATIBLE with a sustainable food system”
3. There is not enough information to definitively say that climate change is real.
4. There's not much point in me doing anything to make agriculture more sustainable. No-one else is going to.
5. Some communities are more affected than others by the global agri-food system, but this is not a priority issue.
6. I'm not going to do anything to address the impacts of the agri-food system because it is not a major issue.
7. Agricultural subsidies should promote sustainable, pesticide and antibiotic-free production.
8. Strong regulation of food production will eventually damage our economic relationship with other countries
9. The main focus of planning for adaptation should be to prepare the food system for extreme weather events, such as drought and flooding. 
10. Climate variation is normal, so why should this be a problem?
11. I am happy to pay a higher price for local or organic food products
12. The negative effects of the climate change on local commerce should be taken into account.
13. I believe that the difference we can have as an individual, in Switzerland, is so minimal that our actions are worthless.
14. It is important to support smal land local farming as they have the fewest resources to deal with impacts of climate change. 
15. We need to focus on adaptation actions that are concerned with the economic future of the country.
16. It is NOT necessary to engage with the community when deciding what are the most important issues for planning for food system changes.
17. The Swiss food system is particularly vulnerable to climate change, and it is in our interest to help find an effective global solution.
18. There is not enough information to definitively establish if the link between the agri-food system and climate change is real.
19. Agriculture is already very sustainable. Swiss farmers are on the right track
20. Sustainable agriculture increases prices and harms consumer freedom. The production should be adapted to what people demand.
21. As long as we use animals in agriculture, it cannot be sustainable
22. Banning pesticides might help the local biodiversity but decreases our food production capacity and autonomy
23. “Farmers already suffer enough from strict rules and paperwork. Family farmers should have more liberties”
24. I don't know what to do. I'm very concerned and would like to do something, but I don't have a realistic shortlist of things that would really make a difference.
25. “Actions on the food system in Switzerland will lead to increased imports and shift of the pollution abroad”
26. Products that use environmentally harmful ingredients, such as palm oil, should be taxed in the same way as tobacco products.
27. The community should be involved in discussions about food system adaptation.
28. “Intensive food production can go along with the protection of the environment and health”
29. I think it is safe to say climate change is here.
30. We should focus on protecting human systems rather than environmental ecosystems.
31. It is important to plan for migration by people displaced by malnutrition and famine.
32. If Switzerland reduces greenhouse gases of its food system it won't make a difference.
33. Climate warming will ultimately benefit food production globally as plants better growth in higher temperature
34. We need actions to protect inhabitants and the biodiversity from harmful pesticide.
35. We need to deal with the water pollution issue through measures such as reducing fertilizer and pesticide use.
36. Climate change will not be a problem because there will be technological solutions available.
37. I don't trust what I hear about climate change from government.
38. There is no urgent need to prepare for an increase in illness and death caused by intensive use of pesticides/antibiotics
39. We should develop short distribution channels and support local production instead of supporting big agrifood corporations
40. I don't trust what scientists say about climate change.
41. The Swiss food system depends on imports from other countries, and it is in our interest to help find an effective global solution.
42. Planning for food system adaptation needs a holistic approach, considering a whole range of issues, instead of focussing on individual issues. 
43. Eating sustainably is too expensive, and only wealthy people can afford it

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Policies that emphasise fewer regulations (e.g., policies that promote free trade agreements by reducing food regulation)
2. Policies that create incentives for local producers to produce sustainable food (e.g., subsidies or tax breaks for local farmers who produce organic products)
3. Adaptation policies and expenditure. Planning controls and emergency response programs.
4. Preparing for climate risk for food production through the development of new approaches and technologies that enhance resilience to the impacts of climate variability or change.
5. Leave the policy settings as they are.
6. Policies that involve a moderate sustainable regulations (e.g., banning certain types of pesticides, incentivising organic agriculture)
7. Policies that involve a radical sustainable food regulation (e.g., banning all pesticides, banning the importation of food related product that employ non-sustanable approaches, exclusively incentivising organic agriculture)

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritized policies promoting sustainable food production and regulations that balance environmental and economic concerns.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 43 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 43 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 43 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Sustainable agriculture increases prices and harms consumer freedom. The production should be adapted to what people demand.
2. Strong regulation of food production will eventually damage our economic relationship with other countries
3. The Swiss food system depends on imports from other countries, and it is in our interest to help find an effective global solution.
4. The community should be involved in discussions about food system adaptation.
5. I believe that the difference we can have as an individual, in Switzerland, is so minimal that our actions are worthless.
6. I'm not going to do anything to address the impacts of the agri-food system because it is not a major issue.
7. As long as we use animals in agriculture, it cannot be sustainable
8. It is important to support smal land local farming as they have the fewest resources to deal with impacts of climate change. 
9. Climate variation is normal, so why should this be a problem?
10. There is no urgent need to prepare for an increase in illness and death caused by intensive use of pesticides/antibiotics
11. It is important to plan for migration by people displaced by malnutrition and famine.
12. Some communities are more affected than others by the global agri-food system, but this is not a priority issue.
13. I don't know what to do. I'm very concerned and would like to do something, but I don't have a realistic shortlist of things that would really make a difference.
14. I think it is safe to say climate change is here.
15. The negative effects of the climate change on local commerce should be taken into account.
16. There is not enough information to definitively establish if the link between the agri-food system and climate change is real.
17. “Actions on the food system in Switzerland will lead to increased imports and shift of the pollution abroad”
18. I am happy to pay a higher price for local or organic food products
19. I don't trust what I hear about climate change from government.
20. “Intensive food production can go along with the protection of the environment and health”
21. We need actions to protect inhabitants and the biodiversity from harmful pesticide.
22. It is NOT necessary to engage with the community when deciding what are the most important issues for planning for food system changes.
23. We need to focus on adaptation actions that are concerned with the economic future of the country.
24. The main focus of planning for adaptation should be to prepare the food system for extreme weather events, such as drought and flooding. 
25. Eating sustainably is too expensive, and only wealthy people can afford it
26. Banning pesticides might help the local biodiversity but decreases our food production capacity and autonomy
27. We need to deal with the water pollution issue through measures such as reducing fertilizer and pesticide use.
28. Climate warming will ultimately benefit food production globally as plants better growth in higher temperature
29. There's not much point in me doing anything to make agriculture more sustainable. No-one else is going to.
30. Planning for food system adaptation needs a holistic approach, considering a whole range of issues, instead of focussing on individual issues. 
31. Products that use environmentally harmful ingredients, such as palm oil, should be taxed in the same way as tobacco products.
32. We should focus on protecting human systems rather than environmental ecosystems.
33. Climate change will not be a problem because there will be technological solutions available.
34. “Food accessibility (price) and security (availability) is NOT COMPATIBLE with a sustainable food system”
35. Agricultural subsidies should promote sustainable, pesticide and antibiotic-free production.
36. We should develop short distribution channels and support local production instead of supporting big agrifood corporations
37. “Farmers already suffer enough from strict rules and paperwork. Family farmers should have more liberties”
38. Agriculture is already very sustainable. Swiss farmers are on the right track
39. The Swiss food system is particularly vulnerable to climate change, and it is in our interest to help find an effective global solution.
40. I don't trust what scientists say about climate change.
41. It's difficult to trust what comes out in the media on the issue of climate change.
42. If Switzerland reduces greenhouse gases of its food system it won't make a difference.
43. There is not enough information to definitively say that climate change is real.

3. Policies that involve a radical sustainable food regulation (e.g., banning all pesticides, banning the importation of food related product that employ non-sustanable approaches, exclusively incentivising organic agriculture)
4. Leave the policy settings as they are.
5. Adaptation policies and expenditure. Planning controls and emergency response programs.
6. Preparing for climate risk for food production through the development of new approaches and technologies that enhance resilience to the impacts of climate variability or change.
7. Policies that involve a moderate sustainable regulations (e.g., banning certain types of pesticides, incentivising organic agriculture)

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritized policies promoting sustainable food production and moderate regulations.

## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
2.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
3. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
4. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
5. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
6. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
7. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
8. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
9. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
10. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
11. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
12. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.
13. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
14. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
15. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
16. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
17. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
18. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
19. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
20. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
21. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
22. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
23. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
24. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
25. If the cost of greenhouse gas emissions is factored in, the cost of renewables compared to coal isn't so big.
26. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
27. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
28. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
29. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
30. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
31. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
32. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
33. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
34. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
35. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
36. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
37. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
38. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
39. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
40. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
41. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.
42. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
43. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
44. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.
45. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.

## [Considerations]:
1. the fusion is a leap in the unknown
2. the amalgamation will erease the local diversities
3. the amalgamation will benefit the emplyees and the citizens. The emplyees will increase their competences through more trainings. Therefore the citizens will benefit of more specialized professionals.
4. the shift from the union to the fusion is a step to big which brings too many uncertainties. If things are done more gradually the change will be hurtless because people will be already used to it.
5. it is not possible to say yes or not to the amalgamation without knowing how it will be, how much will it cost and how it will be done.
6. through the fusion we will be able to derogare il patto di stabilita' and therefore unblock some founds. The latter can be invested in the municipalities that are more in need 
7. it is not necessary to be big to be good. The small municipalities can be better managed of the bigger and do more things. It is a matter of good administration.
8. the choice of the fusion is due to the wish of certain political parties to maintain the political dominance
9. if the fusion will not be done, the single municipalities will not be capable of maintaining the current quality of the services.
10. the fusion is necessary to lower the taxes
11. it is not worth to make the amalgamation in this time of reorganization with the metropolitan bologna
12. the fusion is the right answer to the limit of the union
13. the fusion will bring the resources to make the intervention that our territory needs, like the bycicle paths or the public transport between the municipalities or the high school.
14. it is not yet clear how are they are going to amalgamate the contracts of the municipal clerks across the territory. things like these should be decided before the amalgamtion.
15. with or without the amalgamation, the important thing that is at the practical level, nothing will change. For example the offices should stay where they are.
16. with the amalgamation there will be a deficit of democracy because the municipalities will be only consultive. The citizens will have no power
17. the fusion is not the only solution to the issues of our territory but it is the more concrete
18. the fusion will change our relationship with the administration. The fusionwill move away the administration and the power from the local territory and centralizing it somwhere else
19. the fusion is an innovative process that will make as an example to follow for italy and the rest of europe.
20. there are not enoughf elements do decide in favor or against the fusion
21. the amalgsmation will offer the possibility of save money by cutting the political costs and the burocracy costs and making the administration more efficient.
22. the consequence of the fusion is that either we will pay more than before or they will cut the services
23. through the fusion we will be able to exploit the potentials of the territory to improve the building-, commercial- handcraft- and agricoltural development.
24. in this days of crisis and changes at the european level, the amalgamation is necessary and opportune.
25. the fusion is too risky because is a oneway process
26. in this fusion there is no project, no vision and nos trategy. Things should be done in a very different way.
27. the needs of the citizens are too different acros the municipalities. It will be too difficult for The amalgameted municipality to answer to everybody.
28. the fusion benefits the bigger mnicipalities at the detriment of the smalles also with respect to the external fundings.
29. the fusion is a decision that has already been taken and they are trying to imposing it top down. They are trying to sell the product "amalgamated municipality"
30. the union is a failure and a cost, because it absorbed just a very small part of the services and the money
31. the new municipality will be politically more powerful in front of other municipalities like Bologna metropolitan. In this way our interests will be protected outside our municiplity.
32. the fusion seem to me another way to change everything to change nothing
33. we are misusing the fusion. The needs of the territory are not being respected and the valsmaoggia is being used as a labrat
34. I would not like that the money of my taxes would be used in the municiplities next to mine
35. if the administration chose for the fusion it means that it is the right choice. This choice should be taken by the experts not the citizens
36. the fusion is a samll step to complete a path of amalgamation that started 20 years ago. The amalgamated municipality it is a realty in facts. How much do we have to wait still?
