## [Considerations]:
1. Race is a useful topic for genetic studies
2. People should always be able to withdraw their sample from research at any time.
3. I should have property rights to my tissues before and after they leave my body
4. Collecting samples from people in an ethnic or cultural group is acceptable only if the whole group has agreed to participate.
5. Genetic studies will lead to the discrimination of people living with genetic conditions or disabilities.
6. Commercial companies should keep all the profits they make from biobanking because they take the financial risks and put up the money to develop new drugs and treatments.
7. Religious groups need to be asked for their views about biobanks and genetic research.
8. I trust biobanks with managers who are independent of researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
9. The priorities for health should be to reduce inequalities and the burden of disease.
10. Commercial companies should get access to biobanks, otherwise new drugs and treatments will not be developed.
11. The community that provides samples for research should receive improved medical services in return.
12. I trust researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
13. I do not mind if my sample is connected to my name and medical information.
14. The fact that we cannot predict what biobanks will be used for in the future bothers me.
15. People should be paid for providing their samples to a biobank.
16. It is always acceptable to do research on samples that identify me, without my prior permission.
17. Policy makers need to consider whether WA should not have biobanks.
18. I trust independent research ethics committees, which are not connected to the biobank in anyway, to decide whether research is ethical and approve who gets access to my samples.
19. There must be special consideration of the views of Aboriginal people towards healthcare and genetic research.
20. Deciding how to regulate biobanks should be left to the government.
21. Permission from the indigenous community must be sought if samples are collected from indigenous peoples.
22. The confidentiality of personal medical information is critical in any circumstance where research is being conducted.
23. My sample should never be permanently anonymized since I should be contacted about important research results
24. There is no point asking the public for their views on the ethical issues in science and technology.
25. Genetic studies of race on ethnic or cultural groups will lead to the discrimination of those groups.
26. Improved health is more likely to come from educating people about their diet and lifestyle than from biobanks.
27. High-priced genetic research is diverting funds that could be used to promote public health in other ways.
28. The public will be more protected if biobanks are government-funded not privately funded.
29. Information about people's genes and the traits they inherit from their parents is more private than their medical records.
30. There is no risk to the people who provide samples and information to biobanks.
31. It is acceptable for samples and information that doesn't identify me to be sent to researchers overseas.
32. It's OK if data that identifies me is stored in a separate database and replaced in the biobank by a unique non-identifying code.
33. Biobanks are valuable even if they only advance science (e.g. provide new information about diseases) and do not lead to treatments or cures.
34. Biobanks are valuable because they promise huge benefits for our economy.
35. I do not mind if researchers have access to my samples, when there is no way I can be identified.
36. People who provide samples should be active in the set up and ongoing management of biobanks.
37. I should be asked for my permission every time researchers want to use my samples for research
38. Genetic research will improve our lives.
39. People with a [chronic disease or] genetic condition in their family have a responsibility to be involved in genetic research.
40. Biobanks will only lead to high profits and expensive treatments that most people can't afford.
41. We should all provide samples to biobanks because it will benefit everyone.
42. Researchers and institutions (e.g. hospitals and universities) should be allowed to use samples for research but they should not own them.
43. I don't mind if my samples are connected to my medical records without my prior permission, so long as researchers don't get access to any data that identifies me.
44. Profits from biobanking should be shared in some way with the community who provided the samples.
45. Biobanks need to be monitored and reviewed by external, independent people to prevent the misuse of data and samples.
46. The biobank owner should be able to sell any information they have about my genes, if they want to.
47. People who provide samples for research should get special access to the treatments that result from this research.
48. People should be told if commercial companies could get access to their samples and information.
49. Public funds should pay for biobanks, instead of private companies.

## [Considerations]:
1. Limiting the influence of private insurance companies in the Swiss healthcare system would help avoid higher costs without improving the quality of care.
2. The current system encourages excessive use of services once the deductible ('franchise') has been paid, leading to unnecessary treatments and higher overall costs.
3. Health insurance costs should be income-based to make them more affordable for lower-income individuals.
4. Higher tax deductions for medical expenses would help households manage healthcare costs more effectively.
5. More competition in mandatory health insurance, where insurers can offer alternative models, would promote innovation and efficiency in healthcare.
6. A more transparent healthcare system would help people understand costs and make better decisions.
7. More competition among insurance providers would lead to lower prices and better services.
8. Government control of drug prices would prevent pharmaceutical companies from charging excessive prices.
9. A public single-payer health insurance system would reduce administrative and marketing costs, making the healthcare system more affordable overall.
10. A lack of financial support for preventive measures leads to higher healthcare costs in the long run.
11. Less government regulation in health insurance would allow for more competitive pricing.
12. Higher out-of-pocket payments would prevent excessive use of healthcare services.
13. The increasing demand for healthcare services is mainly due to an aging population that requires more medical care.
14. As health insurance premiums rise, more households require financial assistance, such as individual premium subsidies, to afford coverage.
15. Better coordination between primary care, hospitals, and specialists is essential for the effective treatment of chronic diseases.
16. Switzerland currently has a 'two-tier' healthcare system, where wealthier individuals receive better healthcare than others.
17. Hospitals are more interested in maximizing their profits than in ensuring quality and access to healthcare.
18. It is important to involve more private actors in healthcare (e.g., outsourcing administrative tasks in hospitals to specialized companies) to reduce costs.
19. Reducing the scope of mandatory health insurance coverage could help lower overall healthcare costs.
20. Abolishing mandatory health insurance would reduce the financial burden on households.
21. A more centralized healthcare system, such as national hospital planning, would better organize and improve efficiency in healthcare.
22. Reducing bureaucratic inefficiencies and simplifying administrative processes in healthcare could lead to significant cost savings.
23. Income-based health insurance contributions would make insurance fairer for low-income individuals.

- In your response, return an ordered list of 24 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 24 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Reducing bureaucratic inefficiencies and simplifying administrative processes in healthcare could lead to significant cost savings.
2. Government control of drug prices would prevent pharmaceutical companies from charging excessive prices.
3. Less government regulation in health insurance would allow for more competitive pricing.
4. Abolishing mandatory health insurance would reduce the financial burden on households.
5. Higher tax deductions for medical expenses would help households manage healthcare costs more effectively.
6. It is important to involve more private actors in healthcare (e.g., outsourcing administrative tasks in hospitals to specialized companies) to reduce costs.
7. Health insurance costs should be income-based to make them more affordable for lower-income individuals.
8. The increasing demand for healthcare services is mainly due to an aging population that requires more medical care.
9. More competition among insurance providers would lead to lower prices and better services.
10. Reducing the scope of mandatory health insurance coverage could help lower overall healthcare costs.
11. Switzerland currently has a 'two-tier' healthcare system, where wealthier individuals receive better healthcare than others.
12. A lack of financial support for preventive measures leads to higher healthcare costs in the long run.
13. The current system encourages excessive use of services once the deductible ('franchise') has been paid, leading to unnecessary treatments and higher overall costs.
14. A more centralized healthcare system, such as national hospital planning, would better organize and improve efficiency in healthcare.
15. The Swiss healthcare system focuses too much on treating diseases rather than on disease prevention to improve public health.
16. Higher out-of-pocket payments would prevent excessive use of healthcare services.
17. As health insurance premiums rise, more households require financial assistance, such as individual premium subsidies, to afford coverage.
18. Income-based health insurance contributions would make insurance fairer for low-income individuals.
19. Limiting the influence of private insurance companies in the Swiss healthcare system would help avoid higher costs without improving the quality of care.
20. More competition in mandatory health insurance, where insurers can offer alternative models, would promote innovation and efficiency in healthcare.
21. A public single-payer health insurance system would reduce administrative and marketing costs, making the healthcare system more affordable overall.
22. Hospitals are more interested in maximizing their profits than in ensuring quality and access to healthcare.
23. Better coordination between primary care, hospitals, and specialists is essential for the effective treatment of chronic diseases.
24. A more transparent healthcare system would help people understand costs and make better decisions.

4. More government control over pricing and greater financial support (e.g., individual premium subsidies) would help those in need.
5. No changes are needed to the current healthcare system, as it functions well as it is.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 49 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 49 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 49 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. People should always be able to withdraw their sample from research at any time.
2. Religious groups need to be asked for their views about biobanks and genetic research.
3. There must be special consideration of the views of Aboriginal people towards healthcare and genetic research.
4. Genetic studies will lead to the discrimination of people living with genetic conditions or disabilities.
5. People should be paid for providing their samples to a biobank.
6. High-priced genetic research is diverting funds that could be used to promote public health in other ways.
7. Biobanks need to be monitored and reviewed by external, independent people to prevent the misuse of data and samples.
8. It is acceptable for samples and information that doesn't identify me to be sent to researchers overseas.
9. Improved health is more likely to come from educating people about their diet and lifestyle than from biobanks.
10. The biobank owner should be able to sell any information they have about my genes, if they want to.
11. The confidentiality of personal medical information is critical in any circumstance where research is being conducted.
12. The fact that we cannot predict what biobanks will be used for in the future bothers me.
13. Policy makers need to consider whether WA should not have biobanks.
14. Genetic studies of race on ethnic or cultural groups will lead to the discrimination of those groups.
15. Information about people's genes and the traits they inherit from their parents is more private than their medical records.
16. The priorities for health should be to reduce inequalities and the burden of disease.
17. My sample should never be permanently anonymized since I should be contacted about important research results
18. Genetic research will improve our lives.
19. We should all provide samples to biobanks because it will benefit everyone.
20. Collecting samples from people in an ethnic or cultural group is acceptable only if the whole group has agreed to participate.
21. Deciding how to regulate biobanks should be left to the government.
22. I should have property rights to my tissues before and after they leave my body
23. Commercial companies should keep all the profits they make from biobanking because they take the financial risks and put up the money to develop new drugs and treatments.
24. I trust researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
25. I should be asked for my permission every time researchers want to use my samples for research
26. Biobanks are valuable even if they only advance science (e.g. provide new information about diseases) and do not lead to treatments or cures.
27. People who provide samples should be active in the set up and ongoing management of biobanks.
28. I do not mind if my sample is connected to my name and medical information.
29. I trust independent research ethics committees, which are not connected to the biobank in anyway, to decide whether research is ethical and approve who gets access to my samples.
30. People should be told if commercial companies could get access to their samples and information.
31. Profits from biobanking should be shared in some way with the community who provided the samples.
32. I don't mind if my samples are connected to my medical records without my prior permission, so long as researchers don't get access to any data that identifies me.
33. Researchers and institutions (e.g. hospitals and universities) should be allowed to use samples for research but they should not own them.
34. It's OK if data that identifies me is stored in a separate database and replaced in the biobank by a unique non-identifying code.
35. There is no point asking the public for their views on the ethical issues in science and technology.
36. There is no risk to the people who provide samples and information to biobanks.
37. The public will be more protected if biobanks are government-funded not privately funded.
38. Public funds should pay for biobanks, instead of private companies.
39. People who provide samples for research should get special access to the treatments that result from this research.
40. Commercial companies should get access to biobanks, otherwise new drugs and treatments will not be developed.
41. The community that provides samples for research should receive improved medical services in return.
42. I do not mind if researchers have access to my samples, when there is no way I can be identified.
43. Race is a useful topic for genetic studies
44. It is always acceptable to do research on samples that identify me, without my prior permission.
45. People with a [chronic disease or] genetic condition in their family have a responsibility to be involved in genetic research.
46. I trust biobanks with managers who are independent of researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
47. Biobanks will only lead to high profits and expensive treatments that most people can't afford.
48. Permission from the indigenous community must be sought if samples are collected from indigenous peoples.
49. Biobanks are valuable because they promise huge benefits for our economy.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Privately Funded with strong regulation: A BB system where funding is provided mostly by private companies, withstrong government oversight and privacy provisions.
2. Publicly Funded with strong regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
3. Publicly Funded with minimal regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
4. Minimal Government Input: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Fairly relaxed oversight of use of biobanks and  privacy provisions (low level of regulation).
5. High Privacy: Implementation of a (publicy or privately owned) biobanking system where privacy of individuals is paramount. Stored data and biological samples for research requires the authorization of individual donors.
6. Privately Funded with minimal regulation: Minimal regulation of privately run biobanking system with maximum participation of the public. Low privacy provisions.
7. Cautious Implementation: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Very strict oversight of use of biobanks and strong privacy provisions.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritized strong regulation and public funding for biobanking systems to ensure privacy and oversight.

## [Policies]:
1. Minimal Government Input: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Fairly relaxed oversight of use of biobanks and  privacy provisions (low level of regulation).
2. Publicly Funded with minimal regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
3. Privately Funded with strong regulation: A BB system where funding is provided mostly by private companies, withstrong government oversight and privacy provisions.
4. Publicly Funded with strong regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
5. Cautious Implementation: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Very strict oversight of use of biobanks and strong privacy provisions.
6. Privately Funded with minimal regulation: Minimal regulation of privately run biobanking system with maximum participation of the public. Low privacy provisions.
7. High Privacy: Implementation of a (publicy or privately owned) biobanking system where privacy of individuals is paramount. Stored data and biological samples for research requires the authorization of individual donors.

- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritized publicly funded biobanks with strong regulation and high oversight for individual privacy and safety.

- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. High Privacy: Implementation of a (publicy or privately owned) biobanking system where privacy of individuals is paramount. Stored data and biological samples for research requires the authorization of individual donors.
2. Privately Funded with minimal regulation: Minimal regulation of privately run biobanking system with maximum participation of the public. Low privacy provisions.
3. Cautious Implementation: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Very strict oversight of use of biobanks and strong privacy provisions.
4. Privately Funded with strong regulation: A BB system where funding is provided mostly by private companies, withstrong government oversight and privacy provisions.
5. Publicly Funded with strong regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
6. Publicly Funded with minimal regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
7. Minimal Government Input: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Fairly relaxed oversight of use of biobanks and  privacy provisions (low level of regulation).

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritized strong regulation and government oversight for public trust and safety.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 49 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 49 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 49 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. High-priced genetic research is diverting funds that could be used to promote public health in other ways.
2. I trust biobanks with managers who are independent of researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
3. The priorities for health should be to reduce inequalities and the burden of disease.
4. Improved health is more likely to come from educating people about their diet and lifestyle than from biobanks.
5. Commercial companies should keep all the profits they make from biobanking because they take the financial risks and put up the money to develop new drugs and treatments.
6. The community that provides samples for research should receive improved medical services in return.
7. I do not mind if my sample is connected to my name and medical information.
8. Collecting samples from people in an ethnic or cultural group is acceptable only if the whole group has agreed to participate.
9. It's OK if data that identifies me is stored in a separate database and replaced in the biobank by a unique non-identifying code.
10. I should have property rights to my tissues before and after they leave my body
11. I should be asked for my permission every time researchers want to use my samples for research
12. Race is a useful topic for genetic studies
13. There is no point asking the public for their views on the ethical issues in science and technology.
14. Genetic research will improve our lives.
15. Religious groups need to be asked for their views about biobanks and genetic research.
16. It is always acceptable to do research on samples that identify me, without my prior permission.
17. The fact that we cannot predict what biobanks will be used for in the future bothers me.
18. My sample should never be permanently anonymized since I should be contacted about important research results
19. Policy makers need to consider whether WA should not have biobanks.
20. It is acceptable for samples and information that doesn't identify me to be sent to researchers overseas.
21. Genetic studies of race on ethnic or cultural groups will lead to the discrimination of those groups.
22. Deciding how to regulate biobanks should be left to the government.
23. I trust researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
24. Information about people's genes and the traits they inherit from their parents is more private than their medical records.
25. There is no risk to the people who provide samples and information to biobanks.
26. I don't mind if my samples are connected to my medical records without my prior permission, so long as researchers don't get access to any data that identifies me.
27. Researchers and institutions (e.g. hospitals and universities) should be allowed to use samples for research but they should not own them.
28. Permission from the indigenous community must be sought if samples are collected from indigenous peoples.
29. People should be told if commercial companies could get access to their samples and information.
30. Genetic studies will lead to the discrimination of people living with genetic conditions or disabilities.
31. Biobanks will only lead to high profits and expensive treatments that most people can't afford.
32. Biobanks are valuable because they promise huge benefits for our economy.
33. The public will be more protected if biobanks are government-funded not privately funded.
34. People who provide samples should be active in the set up and ongoing management of biobanks.
35. There must be special consideration of the views of Aboriginal people towards healthcare and genetic research.
36. People should be paid for providing their samples to a biobank.
37. People who provide samples for research should get special access to the treatments that result from this research.
38. Biobanks need to be monitored and reviewed by external, independent people to prevent the misuse of data and samples.
39. Profits from biobanking should be shared in some way with the community who provided the samples.
40. Commercial companies should get access to biobanks, otherwise new drugs and treatments will not be developed.
41. The biobank owner should be able to sell any information they have about my genes, if they want to.
42. People should always be able to withdraw their sample from research at any time.
43. The confidentiality of personal medical information is critical in any circumstance where research is being conducted.
44. I do not mind if researchers have access to my samples, when there is no way I can be identified.
45. I trust independent research ethics committees, which are not connected to the biobank in anyway, to decide whether research is ethical and approve who gets access to my samples.
46. People with a [chronic disease or] genetic condition in their family have a responsibility to be involved in genetic research.
47. We should all provide samples to biobanks because it will benefit everyone.
48. Public funds should pay for biobanks, instead of private companies.
49. Biobanks are valuable even if they only advance science (e.g. provide new information about diseases) and do not lead to treatments or cures.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Parents and guardians have a right to edit the genes of their children before they are born.
2. Each individual has a right to decide for themselves whether to undergo gene editing, as long as the changes cannot be passed on to future generations.
3. I'm worried that human genome editing will widen the gap between those who can afford it and those who can't.
4. It's better to use genome editing to prevent a serious disease from happening rather than having to treat it with conventional medicine after it has occurred.
5. Editing genes that will be inherited is problematic because it means making decisions for future people who don't exist yet. 
6. My concern is that as we start to tinker with the human genome, we're going to accidentally introduce a whole host of other problems.
7. I have a more positive feeling about gene editing in humans than I do for animals or plants.
8. I'm concerned that genome editing will lead to a reduction in genetic diversity.
9. If human genome editing can be used to make changes to humans on demand for any reason, the future will be like a dystopian movie.
10. There is nothing wrong with using genome editing to speed up evolution and help living things (including humans) adapt to challenges.
11. Genome editing in agriculture will have the biggest impact on people's health. 
12. I think it would be amazing to have a choice in the way someone behaves.
13. Parents want 'designer babies' with certain traits out of vanity.
14. I'm concerned that genome editing will be used as a quick techno-fix without actually dealing with real problems.
15. I would be OK with having my own genome edited.
16. If genome editing is proven to be safe, then I see no reason to oppose it.
17. I think it's okay to use genome editing to change someone's appearance.
18. Genome editing is really cool science.
19. Anything that's been artificially created in a lab gives me Frankenstein vibes.
20. Beacause of our changing environments, I believe that future humans will need genome editing to survive.
21. Interfering in people's genes is intervening a bit too far in human creation.
22. When you change someone's genes you are fundamentally changing who they are.
23. If we open the box of genome editing we will not know where to draw the line.
24. The idea that people with genetic conditions might get cured in my lifetime is miraculous and incredible.
25. It is better to accept our genes the way they are than to tamper with things we don't understand.
26. My cultural beliefs make me cautious about genome editing.
27. I think we should keep an open mind about new discoveries.
28. I believe we should remain as natural as possible but we should not shy away from furthering medicine and the chance to save lives.
29. I don't think we know enough about genetic diseases or the long term consequences of genome editing
30. If human genome editing is available then it should be available to everyone who needs it, not just those who can afford it.
31. I would consider using genome editing for my children to give them an advantage in life, so long as it's safe.
32. The idea of editing the human genome is scary.
33. Decisions about the use of genome editing are best left to the experts.
34. Genome editing will be used for enhancement by wealthy people.
35. Suggesting genome editing will 'cure' disability diminishes those living with genetic conditions who need support.
36. Mitochondrial donation is a treatment more like an organ transplant, which doesn't really change the genetics of person.
37. Genome editing technologies gives us power over human life itself.
38. Science and technology have too much control over our lives.
39. It's a slippery slope from genome editing for medical reasons to using it for other reasons.
40. We find strength when we face illness and adversity. It makes us who we are. 
41. The idea that genome editing can make perfect people and societies is extremely dangerous.
42. I am concerned that the use of human genome editing will advantage one group over another.
43. I worry that something will go wrong with genome technology.
44. The use of gene editing for non-medical reasons reminds me of the Nazis during the Second World War.
45. As a society, we have an obligation to help strengthen coming generations by eradicating diseases.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 8 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 8, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 8 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 8 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 8 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Permit only non-heritable human genome editing for clinical treatments, and mitochondrial donation.
2. Prohibit all uses of human genome editing and mitochondrial donation.
3. Prohibit all forms of human genome editing for now, except for research purposes.
4. Permit non-heritable and heritable human genome editing (including mitochondrial donation), but only for clinical purposes, and if there is strong oversight, regular community input and (re)approval.
5. Permit only non-heritable human genome editing in both research and in clinics and mitochondrial donation only if not for profit.
6. Permit all uses of human genome editing and mitochondrial donation only if not for profit
7.  Permit both heritable and non-heritable uses of genome editing for any purpose with minimal restrictions to ensure safety and compliance with ethical standards.
8.  Permit only non-heritable human genome editing in both research and in clinics.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritized policies allowing genome editing for clinical purposes with oversight and restrictions.

- In your response, return an ordered list of 8 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 8 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Prohibit all uses of human genome editing and mitochondrial donation.
2. Permit all uses of human genome editing and mitochondrial donation only if not for profit
3. Prohibit all forms of human genome editing for now, except for research purposes.
4.  Permit both heritable and non-heritable uses of genome editing for any purpose with minimal restrictions to ensure safety and compliance with ethical standards.
5.  Permit only non-heritable human genome editing in both research and in clinics.
6. Permit non-heritable and heritable human genome editing (including mitochondrial donation), but only for clinical purposes, and if there is strong oversight, regular community input and (re)approval.
7. Permit only non-heritable human genome editing in both research and in clinics and mitochondrial donation only if not for profit.
8. Permit only non-heritable human genome editing for clinical treatments, and mitochondrial donation.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritized policies allowing non-heritable editing for clinical treatments with oversight and restrictions.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. My concern is that as we start to tinker with the human genome, we're going to accidentally introduce a whole host of other problems.
2. I worry that something will go wrong with genome technology.
3. If we open the box of genome editing we will not know where to draw the line.
4. It's better to use genome editing to prevent a serious disease from happening rather than having to treat it with conventional medicine after it has occurred.
5. If human genome editing is available then it should be available to everyone who needs it, not just those who can afford it.
6. My cultural beliefs make me cautious about genome editing.
7. Science and technology have too much control over our lives.
8. I think it's okay to use genome editing to change someone's appearance.
9. I have a more positive feeling about gene editing in humans than I do for animals or plants.
10. It's a slippery slope from genome editing for medical reasons to using it for other reasons.
11. I think we should keep an open mind about new discoveries.
12. Decisions about the use of genome editing are best left to the experts.
13. I would consider using genome editing for my children to give them an advantage in life, so long as it's safe.
14. I believe we should remain as natural as possible but we should not shy away from furthering medicine and the chance to save lives.
15. Mitochondrial donation is a treatment more like an organ transplant, which doesn't really change the genetics of person.
16. I'm concerned that genome editing will lead to a reduction in genetic diversity.
17. If genome editing is proven to be safe, then I see no reason to oppose it.
18. I think it would be amazing to have a choice in the way someone behaves.
19. Anything that's been artificially created in a lab gives me Frankenstein vibes.
20. The idea that people with genetic conditions might get cured in my lifetime is miraculous and incredible.
21. Editing genes that will be inherited is problematic because it means making decisions for future people who don't exist yet. 
22. I'm concerned that genome editing will be used as a quick techno-fix without actually dealing with real problems.
23. Parents and guardians have a right to edit the genes of their children before they are born.
24. When you change someone's genes you are fundamentally changing who they are.
25. There is nothing wrong with using genome editing to speed up evolution and help living things (including humans) adapt to challenges.
26. Suggesting genome editing will 'cure' disability diminishes those living with genetic conditions who need support.
27. We find strength when we face illness and adversity. It makes us who we are. 
28. The idea that genome editing can make perfect people and societies is extremely dangerous.
29. As a society, we have an obligation to help strengthen coming generations by eradicating diseases.
30. I am concerned that the use of human genome editing will advantage one group over another.
31. Genome editing will be used for enhancement by wealthy people.
32. I don't think we know enough about genetic diseases or the long term consequences of genome editing
33. Interfering in people's genes is intervening a bit too far in human creation.
34. It is better to accept our genes the way they are than to tamper with things we don't understand.
35. Genome editing technologies gives us power over human life itself.
36. Genome editing in agriculture will have the biggest impact on people's health. 
37. I'm worried that human genome editing will widen the gap between those who can afford it and those who can't.
38. Each individual has a right to decide for themselves whether to undergo gene editing, as long as the changes cannot be passed on to future generations.
39. I would be OK with having my own genome edited.
40. Parents want 'designer babies' with certain traits out of vanity.
41. Beacause of our changing environments, I believe that future humans will need genome editing to survive.
42. If human genome editing can be used to make changes to humans on demand for any reason, the future will be like a dystopian movie.
43. The idea of editing the human genome is scary.
44. The use of gene editing for non-medical reasons reminds me of the Nazis during the Second World War.
45. Genome editing is really cool science.

## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. We find strength when we face illness and adversity. It makes us who we are. 
2. Parents and guardians have a right to edit the genes of their children before they are born.
3. Genome editing is really cool science.
4. I think it's okay to use genome editing to change someone's appearance.
5. The use of gene editing for non-medical reasons reminds me of the Nazis during the Second World War.
6. Genome editing technologies gives us power over human life itself.
7. The idea that people with genetic conditions might get cured in my lifetime is miraculous and incredible.
8. My cultural beliefs make me cautious about genome editing.
9. If human genome editing is available then it should be available to everyone who needs it, not just those who can afford it.
10. If genome editing is proven to be safe, then I see no reason to oppose it.
11. The idea that genome editing can make perfect people and societies is extremely dangerous.
12. Beacause of our changing environments, I believe that future humans will need genome editing to survive.
13. I don't think we know enough about genetic diseases or the long term consequences of genome editing
14. Editing genes that will be inherited is problematic because it means making decisions for future people who don't exist yet. 
15. I would consider using genome editing for my children to give them an advantage in life, so long as it's safe.
16. It is better to accept our genes the way they are than to tamper with things we don't understand.
17. My concern is that as we start to tinker with the human genome, we're going to accidentally introduce a whole host of other problems.
18. Genome editing in agriculture will have the biggest impact on people's health. 
19. Suggesting genome editing will 'cure' disability diminishes those living with genetic conditions who need support.
20. I'm concerned that genome editing will be used as a quick techno-fix without actually dealing with real problems.
21. Interfering in people's genes is intervening a bit too far in human creation.
22. Each individual has a right to decide for themselves whether to undergo gene editing, as long as the changes cannot be passed on to future generations.
23. I would be OK with having my own genome edited.
24. I am concerned that the use of human genome editing will advantage one group over another.
25. I'm concerned that genome editing will lead to a reduction in genetic diversity.
26. I'm worried that human genome editing will widen the gap between those who can afford it and those who can't.
27. If human genome editing can be used to make changes to humans on demand for any reason, the future will be like a dystopian movie.
28. Parents want 'designer babies' with certain traits out of vanity.
29. I believe we should remain as natural as possible but we should not shy away from furthering medicine and the chance to save lives.
30. Decisions about the use of genome editing are best left to the experts.
31. If we open the box of genome editing we will not know where to draw the line.
32. When you change someone's genes you are fundamentally changing who they are.
33. As a society, we have an obligation to help strengthen coming generations by eradicating diseases.
34. Anything that's been artificially created in a lab gives me Frankenstein vibes.
35. I think we should keep an open mind about new discoveries.
36. There is nothing wrong with using genome editing to speed up evolution and help living things (including humans) adapt to challenges.
37. Genome editing will be used for enhancement by wealthy people.
38. I worry that something will go wrong with genome technology.
39. Mitochondrial donation is a treatment more like an organ transplant, which doesn't really change the genetics of person.
40. The idea of editing the human genome is scary.
41. I think it would be amazing to have a choice in the way someone behaves.
42. It's a slippery slope from genome editing for medical reasons to using it for other reasons.
43. Science and technology have too much control over our lives.
44. I have a more positive feeling about gene editing in humans than I do for animals or plants.
45. It's better to use genome editing to prevent a serious disease from happening rather than having to treat it with conventional medicine after it has occurred.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 8 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 8, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 8 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 8 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 8 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Permit only non-heritable human genome editing for clinical treatments, and mitochondrial donation.
2.  Permit only non-heritable human genome editing in both research and in clinics.
3. Prohibit all forms of human genome editing for now, except for research purposes.
4. Permit all uses of human genome editing and mitochondrial donation only if not for profit
5.  Permit both heritable and non-heritable uses of genome editing for any purpose with minimal restrictions to ensure safety and compliance with ethical standards.
6. Permit only non-heritable human genome editing in both research and in clinics and mitochondrial donation only if not for profit.
7. Permit non-heritable and heritable human genome editing (including mitochondrial donation), but only for clinical purposes, and if there is strong oversight, regular community input and (re)approval.
8. Prohibit all uses of human genome editing and mitochondrial donation.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritized policies with strong oversight and non-heritable editing for clinical purposes.

- Rate each of the 35 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 35 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].

1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. More scientific research is needed before we can say if climate change is a threat to the Great Barrier Reef.
2. Protection of the Great Barrier Reef is worthwhile at whatever cost.
3. I think enough is being done to effectively manage the Great Barrier Reef.
4. Economic development associated with mining will provide more opportunities for future generations in North Queensland.
5. We don't need to worry too much about environmental damage in the Great Barrier Reef because future generations will be better able to deal with these problems than we are.
6. If we are serious about maintaining and improving people's living standards in Townsville, we need to make the most out of coal exports.
7. If future generations could have their say about the Great Barrier Reef, they would be less concerned about the environmental impacts than many people make out.
8. Government should be doing more to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
9. The negative publicity about climate change impacts on the reef has negatively affected the local tourism industry.
10. Townsville is better off because of mining development.
11. There are more jobs to lose from Great Barrier Reef tourism than to be gained from the coal industry.
12. Coal-generated electricity must be phased out if we are to avoid catastrophic impacts of global warming, including the loss of the Great Barrier Reef.
13. The Great Barrier Reef underpins more direct and indirect jobs than mining does. 
14. The Great Barrier Reef is a great asset for the economy of this region and we should prioritise protecting it.
15. It is not possible to conserve the reef over the long term without addressing climate change 
16. I feel that future generations have been adequately considered in the management of the Great Barrier Reef.
17. Mining development in Australia is a risk to the environment.
18. Deep-pocketed green groups are willing to sacrifice our local economy for their own goals. 
19. A few self-interested politicians and influential companies are prepared to sacrifice our well-being for their own short-term gain.
20. We should prioritise protecting the environment in Townsville, even if it hurts our economy.
21. Jobs and growth in Townsville should be prioritised over Great Barrier Reef protection.
22. Each new Australian coal mine will contribute greenhouse emissions that exacerbate the risk of climate change, and impacts to the Reef.
23. Climate change is an immediate threat requiring action.
24. There is no strong scientific evidence to suggest that the Great Barrier Reef is under threat from climate change.
25. Government should provide funding support for industry, including mining projects such as the Adani mine.
26. The first priority should be reducing other pressures on the reef (such as agricultural runoff or coastal development) so that the reef will be more resilient to climate change impacts. 
27. Climate change impacts on the Great Barrier Reef aren't something I'm worried about.
28. Australia's contribution to global greenhouse gas emissions is so small that we should wait for other countries to take action on climate change before we do. 
29. Short term development thinking will ultimately lead to longer term reef damage and economic impacts.
30. There is no point throwing money at protecting the reef if our other actions contribute to its continuing decline.
31. If we don't take steps to protect the Great Barrier Reef future generations will miss out on the opportunity to experience the reef.
32. Climate change is a threat, but the impacts are too distant for immediate concern.
33. The mining industry provides thousands of jobs. Without it unemployment would have skyrocketed in regional Queensland.
34. While job creation is important, we should prioritise industries that have less impact on the reef over those that have greater impact on the reef. 
35. We should prioritise economic development and job creation in Townsville over the environment.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Strengthen environmental protection regulations, such as regulation around mining and agriculture, to better protect the reef.
2. Maintain current mixture of industries, land uses and practices (e.g. mining, refineries, agriculture and tourism).
3. Reduce current environmental regulations to boost local business.
4. No new coal mines, close all existing coal-fired power plants as soon as possible.
5. Invest in innovation and the development of environmentally-friendly practices and industries (e.g. eco-tourism, sustainable agriculture). 
6. Maintain current levels of environmental protection.
7. Reduce funding for extractive and resource-intensive industries.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritizing environmental protection and reducing coal mining to preserve the Great Barrier Reef.

2. I think enough is being done to effectively manage the Great Barrier Reef.
3. Mining development in Australia is a risk to the environment.
4. Each new Australian coal mine will contribute greenhouse emissions that exacerbate the risk of climate change, and impacts to the Reef.
5. If we don't take steps to protect the Great Barrier Reef future generations will miss out on the opportunity to experience the reef.
6. Jobs and growth in Townsville should be prioritised over Great Barrier Reef protection.
7. Townsville is better off because of mining development.
8. The negative publicity about climate change impacts on the reef has negatively affected the local tourism industry.
9. If future generations could have their say about the Great Barrier Reef, they would be less concerned about the environmental impacts than many people make out.
10. We should prioritise economic development and job creation in Townsville over the environment. 
11. It is not possible to conserve the reef over the long term without addressing climate change 
12. Economic development associated with mining will provide more opportunities for future generations in North Queensland.
13. There is no strong scientific evidence to suggest that the Great Barrier Reef is under threat from climate change.
14. The Great Barrier Reef underpins more direct and indirect jobs than mining does. 
15. More scientific research is needed before we can say if climate change is a threat to the Great Barrier Reef.
16. Climate change impacts on the Great Barrier Reef aren't something I'm worried about.
17. We don't need to worry too much about environmental damage in the Great Barrier Reef because future generations will be better able to deal with these problems than we are.
18. Climate change is a threat, but the impacts are too distant for immediate concern.
19. Short term development thinking will ultimately lead to longer term reef damage and economic impacts.
20. Government should be doing more to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
21. The first priority should be reducing other pressures on the reef (such as agricultural runoff or coastal development) so that the reef will be more resilient to climate change impacts. 
22. Coal-generated electricity must be phased out if we are to avoid catastrophic impacts of global warming, including the loss of the Great Barrier Reef.
23. We should prioritise protecting the environment in Townsville, even if it hurts our economy.
24. There is no point throwing money at protecting the reef if our other actions contribute to its continuing decline.
25. Protection of the Great Barrier Reef is worthwhile at whatever cost.
26. While job creation is important, we should prioritise industries that have less impact on the reef over those that have greater impact on the reef. 
27. Climate change is an immediate threat requiring action.
28. I feel that future generations have been adequately considered in the management of the Great Barrier Reef.
29. A few self-interested politicians and influential companies are prepared to sacrifice our well-being for their own short-term gain.
30. Government should provide funding support for industry, including mining projects such as the Adani mine.
31. Deep-pocketed green groups are willing to sacrifice our local economy for their own goals. 
32. The Great Barrier Reef is a great asset for the economy of this region and we should prioritise protecting it.
33. There are more jobs to lose from Great Barrier Reef tourism than to be gained from the coal industry.
34. If we are serious about maintaining and improving people's living standards in Townsville, we need to make the most out of coal exports.
35. The mining industry provides thousands of jobs. Without it unemployment would have skyrocketed in regional Queensland.

- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.

3. Maintain current levels of environmental protection.
4. Maintain current mixture of industries, land uses and practices (e.g. mining, refineries, agriculture and tourism).
5. Strengthen environmental protection regulations, such as regulation around mining and agriculture, to better protect the reef.
6. Reduce funding for extractive and resource-intensive industries. 
7. Reduce current environmental regulations to boost local business.

- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.

24. The Great Barrier Reef underpins more direct and indirect jobs than mining does. 
25. Protection of the Great Barrier Reef is worthwhile at whatever cost.
26. Coal-generated electricity must be phased out if we are to avoid catastrophic impacts of global warming, including the loss of the Great Barrier Reef.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 36 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- Using the Q Methodology, rate the statements following a Fixed Quasi-Normal Distribution between 1 and 11.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 36 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 36 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. it is not yet clear how are they are going to amalgamate the contracts of the municipal clerks across the territory. things like these should be decided before the amalgamtion.
2. the amalgamation will erease the local diversities
3. the fusion seem to me another way to change everything to change nothing
4. the fusion is a samll step to complete a path of amalgamation that started 20 years ago. The amalgamated municipality it is a realty in facts. How much do we have to wait still?
5. I would not like that the money of my taxes would be used in the municiplities next to mine
6. the fusion is a decision that has already been taken and they are trying to imposing it top down. They are trying to sell the product "amalgamated municipality"
7. the amalgsmation will offer the possibility of save money by cutting the political costs and the burocracy costs and making the administration more efficient.
8. with the amalgamation there will be a deficit of democracy because the municipalities will be only consultive. The citizens will have no power
9. the fusion is too risky because is a oneway process
10. the consequence of the fusion is that either we will pay more than before or they will cut the services
11. the choice of the fusion is due to the wish of certain political parties to maintain the political dominance
12. it is not worth to make the amalgamation in this time of reorganization with the metropolitan bologna
13. the new municipality will be politically more powerful in front of other municipalities like Bologna metropolitan. In this way our interests will be protected outside our municiplity.
14. through the fusion we will be able to exploit the potentials of the territory to improve the building-, commercial- handcraft- and agricoltural development.
15. it is not necessary to be big to be good. The small municipalities can be better managed of the bigger and do more things. It is a matter of good administration.
16. through the fusion we will be able to derogare il patto di stabilita' and therefore unblock some founds. The latter can be invested in the municipalities that are more in need 
17. the fusion benefits the bigger mnicipalities at the detriment of the smalles also with respect to the external fundings.
18. in this fusion there is no project, no vision and nos trategy. Things should be done in a very different way.
19. we are misusing the fusion. The needs of the territory are not being respected and the valsmaoggia is being used as a labrat
20. there are not enoughf elements do decide in favor or against the fusion
21. it is not possible to say yes or not to the amalgamation without knowing how it will be, how much will it cost and how it will be done.
22. the fusion will bring the resources to make the intervention that our territory needs, like the bycicle paths or the public transport between the municipalities or the high school.
23. the fusion is necessary to lower the taxes
24. if the administration chose for the fusion it means that it is the right choice. This choice should be taken by the experts not the citizens
25. the shift from the union to the fusion is a step to big which brings too many uncertainties. If things are done more gradually the change will be hurtless because people will be already used to it.
26. the fusion is an innovative process that will make as an example to follow for italy and the rest of europe.
27. the fusion is not the only solution to the issues of our territory but it is the more concrete
28. with or without the amalgamation, the important thing that is at the practical level, nothing will change. For example the offices should stay where they are.
29. the fusion will change our relationship with the administration. The fusionwill move away the administration and the power from the local territory and centralizing it somwhere else
30. the fusion is a leap in the unknown
31. if the fusion will not be done, the single municipalities will not be capable of maintaining the current quality of the services.
32. in this days of crisis and changes at the european level, the amalgamation is necessary and opportune.
33. the needs of the citizens are too different acros the municipalities. It will be too difficult for The amalgameted municipality to answer to everybody.
34. the union is a failure and a cost, because it absorbed just a very small part of the services and the money
35. the amalgamation will benefit the emplyees and the citizens. The emplyees will increase their competences through more trainings. Therefore the citizens will benefit of more specialized professionals.
36. the fusion is the right answer to the limit of the union

3. the amalgamation will erease the local diversities
4. with the amalgamation there will be a deficit of democracy because the municipalities will be only consultive. The citizens will have no power
5. through the fusion we will be able to exploit the potentials of the territory to improve the building-, commercial- handcraft- and agricoltural development.

8. the fusion is a leap in the unknown

2. the fusion will change our relationship with the administration. The fusionwill move away the administration and the power from the local territory and centralizing it somwhere else
3. the fusion is a leap in the unknown
4. if the administration chose for the fusion it means that it is the right choice. This choice should be taken by the experts not the citizens
5. through the fusion we will be able to derogare il patto di stabilita' and therefore unblock some founds. The latter can be invested in the municipalities that are more in need 
6. the fusion seem to me another way to change everything to change nothing
7. the fusion is not the only solution to the issues of our territory but it is the more concrete
8. it is not yet clear how are they are going to amalgamate the contracts of the municipal clerks across the territory. things like these should be decided before the amalgamtion.
9. it is not worth to make the amalgamation in this time of reorganization with the metropolitan bologna
10. the fusion benefits the bigger mnicipalities at the detriment of the smalles also with respect to the external fundings.
11. with or without the amalgamation, the important thing that is at the practical level, nothing will change. For example the offices should stay where they are.
12. the shift from the union to the fusion is a step to big which brings too many uncertainties. If things are done more gradually the change will be hurtless because people will be already used to it.
13. it is not possible to say yes or not to the amalgamation without knowing how it will be, how much will it cost and how it will be done.
14. the fusion is the right answer to the limit of the union
15. the choice of the fusion is due to the wish of certain political parties to maintain the political dominance
16. the fusion will bring the resources to make the intervention that our territory needs, like the bycicle paths or the public transport between the municipalities or the high school.
17. the consequence of the fusion is that either we will pay more than before or they will cut the services
18. the fusion is too risky because is a oneway process
19. the needs of the citizens are too different acros the municipalities. It will be too difficult for The amalgameted municipality to answer to everybody.
20. there are not enoughf elements do decide in favor or against the fusion
21. it is not necessary to be big to be good. The small municipalities can be better managed of the bigger and do more things. It is a matter of good administration.
22. we are misusing the fusion. The needs of the territory are not being respected and the valsmaoggia is being used as a labrat
23. the amalgamation will benefit the emplyees and the citizens. The emplyees will increase their competences through more trainings. Therefore the citizens will benefit of more specialized professionals.
24. through the fusion we will be able to exploit the potentials of the territory to improve the building-, commercial- handcraft- and agricoltural development.
25. the new municipality will be politically more powerful in front of other municipalities like Bologna metropolitan. In this way our interests will be protected outside our municiplity.
26. the fusion is a samll step to complete a path of amalgamation that started 20 years ago. The amalgamated municipality it is a realty in facts. How much do we have to wait still?
27. in this days of crisis and changes at the european level, the amalgamation is necessary and opportune.
28. the amalgsmation will offer the possibility of save money by cutting the political costs and the burocracy costs and making the administration more efficient.
29. the union is a failure and a cost, because it absorbed just a very small part of the services and the money
30. with the amalgamation there will be a deficit of democracy because the municipalities will be only consultive. The citizens will have no power
31. the fusion is a decision that has already been taken and they are trying to imposing it top down. They are trying to sell the product "amalgamated municipality"
32. the fusion is necessary to lower the taxes
33. if the fusion will not be done, the single municipalities will not be capable of maintaining the current quality of the services.
34. the amalgamation will erease the local diversities
35. in this fusion there is no project, no vision and nos trategy. Things should be done in a very different way.
36. I would not like that the money of my taxes would be used in the municiplities next to mine

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 4 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 4, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 4 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 4 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].

- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

7. the fusion is a leap in the unknown

11. the fusion seem to me another way to change everything to change nothing
12. the choice of the fusion is due to the wish of certain political parties to maintain the political dominance
13. through the fusion we will be able to derogare il patto di stabilita' and therefore unblock some founds. The latter can be invested in the municipalities that are more in need

31. the fusion is the right answer to the limit of the union

33. the amalgamation will erease the local diversities

35. the fusion will bring the resources to make the intervention that our territory needs, like the bycicle paths or the public transport between the municipalities or the high school.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
2. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
3. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
4. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
5. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
6. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
7. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
8. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
9. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
10. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
11. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
12. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.
13. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
14. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
15. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
16. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
17. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
18. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
19. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
20. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
21. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
22. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
23. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.
24. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
25.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
26. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
27. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
28. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
29. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.
30. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
31. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
32. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
33. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
34. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
35. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
36. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
37. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.
38. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
39. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
