## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
2. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
3. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
4.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
5. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
6. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
7. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
8. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
9. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
10. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
11. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
12. If the cost of greenhouse gas emissions is factored in, the cost of renewables compared to coal isn't so big.
13. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
14. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
15. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
16. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.
17. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
18. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
19. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
20. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
21. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
22. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
23. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
24. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
25. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
26. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.
27. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
28. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
29. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
30. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
31. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
32. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
33. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.
34. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
35. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
36. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
37. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
38. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
39. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
40. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
41. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
42. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
43. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
44. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
45. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
2. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
3. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
4. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.
5. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
6. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
7. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
8. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
9. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
10. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
11. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
12. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
13. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
14. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
15. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
16. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
17. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
18. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
19. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
20. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
21. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
22. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.
23. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
24. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
25. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
26. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
27. If the cost of greenhouse gas emissions is factored in, the cost of renewables compared to coal isn't so big.
28. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
29. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
30.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
31. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
32. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
33. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
34. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
35. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
36. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
37. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
38. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
39. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
40. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.
41. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
42. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
43. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
44. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
45. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.

## [Considerations]:
1. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
2. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
3. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
4. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
5. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
6. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
7. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
8. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
9. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.
10. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
11. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
12. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
13. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
14. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
15. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.
16. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
17.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
18. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
19. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
20. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.
21. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
22. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
23. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
24. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
25. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
26. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
27. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
28. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
29. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
30. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
31. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
32. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.
33. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
34. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
35. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
36. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
37. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
38. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
39. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
40. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
41. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
42. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
43. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
44. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
45. If the cost of greenhouse gas emissions is factored in, the cost of renewables compared to coal isn't so big.

## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
2. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
3. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
4. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
5. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
6. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
7. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
8. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
9. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
10. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
11. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
12. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
13. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
14. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.
15. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
16. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
17. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
18. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
19. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.
20. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
21. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
22. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.
23. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
24. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
25. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.
26. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
27. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
28.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
29. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
30. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
31. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
32. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
33. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
34. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
35. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
36. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
37. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
38. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
39. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
40. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
41. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
42. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
43. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
44. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
45. If the cost of greenhouse gas emissions is factored in, the cost of renewables compared to coal isn't so big.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 9 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 9, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 9 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 9 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 9 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Geothermal Energy
2. Wind
3. Coal
4. Natural Gas
5. Coal with CO2 Burial
6. Hydroelectric
7. Biomass
8. Solar Energy
9. Nuclear Energy

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritized renewable energy sources and lower greenhouse gas emissions options.

2. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
3. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.
4. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
5. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.
6. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
7. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
8. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
9. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
10.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
11. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
12. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
13. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
14. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
15. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
16. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
17. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
18. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
19. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
20. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.
21. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
22. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
23. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
24. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
25. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
26. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
27. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
28. If the cost of greenhouse gas emissions is factored in, the cost of renewables compared to coal isn't so big.
29. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
30. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
31. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
32. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
33. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
34. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
35. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.
36. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
37. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
38. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
39. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
40. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
41. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
42. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
43. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
44. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
45. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.

3. I don't trust what scientists say about climate change.
4. There's not much point in me doing anything to make agriculture more sustainable. No-one else is going to.
5. “Actions on the food system in Switzerland will lead to increased imports and shift of the pollution abroad”
6. The main focus of planning for adaptation should be to prepare the food system for extreme weather events, such as drought and flooding. 
7. The Swiss food system is particularly vulnerable to climate change, and it is in our interest to help find an effective global solution.
8. I don't trust what I hear about climate change from government.
9. Sustainable agriculture increases prices and harms consumer freedom. The production should be adapted to what people demand.
10. Eating sustainably is too expensive, and only wealthy people can afford it

12. It is important to plan for migration by people displaced by malnutrition and famine.
13. The Swiss food system depends on imports from other countries, and it is in our interest to help find an effective global solution.
14. Agriculture is already very sustainable. Swiss farmers are on the right track

20. We need actions to protect inhabitants and the biodiversity from harmful pesticide.
21. Climate warming will ultimately benefit food production globally as plants better growth in higher temperature
22. We need to focus on adaptation actions that are concerned with the economic future of the country.
23. The community should be involved in discussions about food system adaptation.
24. Some communities are more affected than others by the global agri-food system, but this is not a priority issue.
25. We should focus on protecting human systems rather than environmental ecosystems.
26. I don't know what to do. I'm very concerned and would like to do something, but I don't have a realistic shortlist of things that would really make a difference.
27. The negative effects of the climate change on local commerce should be taken into account.
28. Strong regulation of food production will eventually damage our economic relationship with other countries
29. There is not enough information to definitively say that climate change is real.
30. Banning pesticides might help the local biodiversity but decreases our food production capacity and autonomy
31. As long as we use animals in agriculture, it cannot be sustainable
32. “Food accessibility (price) and security (availability) is NOT COMPATIBLE with a sustainable food system”
33. It is important to support smal land local farming as they have the fewest resources to deal with impacts of climate change. 
34. Climate variation is normal, so why should this be a problem?
35. “Intensive food production can go along with the protection of the environment and health”
36. There is no urgent need to prepare for an increase in illness and death caused by intensive use of pesticides/antibiotics
37. Climate change will not be a problem because there will be technological solutions available.
38. If Switzerland reduces greenhouse gases of its food system it won't make a difference.
39. It's difficult to trust what comes out in the media on the issue of climate change.

## [Policies]:
1. Policies that involve a radical sustainable food regulation (e.g., banning all pesticides, banning the importation of food related product that employ non-sustanable approaches, exclusively incentivising organic agriculture)
2. Preparing for climate risk for food production through the development of new approaches and technologies that enhance resilience to the impacts of climate variability or change.
3. Adaptation policies and expenditure. Planning controls and emergency response programs.
4. Policies that involve a moderate sustainable regulations (e.g., banning certain types of pesticides, incentivising organic agriculture)
5. Leave the policy settings as they are.
6. Policies that create incentives for local producers to produce sustainable food (e.g., subsidies or tax breaks for local farmers who produce organic products)
7. Policies that emphasise fewer regulations (e.g., policies that promote free trade agreements by reducing food regulation)

14. Mental health can be understood in different ways. A comprehensive definition of mental health should take into account social issues such as poverty, inequality, and discrimination.

16. Mental health issues require less urgency and fewer resources compared to physical health conditions.

18. To prevent people with mental health issues from feeling lonely or isolated, we should talk more about these topics in schools and workplaces to increase public understanding and sensitivity.
19. Focusing on prevention strategies (e.g., government media campaigns) is essential to reducing the impact of stigma associated with mental health conditions.
